(A) Schematic diagram of a differentially pumped TEM column [123]. Reproduced with permission. Copyright 2012, Elsevier. (A) Schematic illustration of an MEMS-based liquid cell to accommodate the liquid environment between two windowed SiN x membranes [127]. Reproduced with permission. Copyright 2011, Springer Nature. Copyright 2014, American Association for the Advancement of Science. (A) In situ HAADF-STEM images showing the structural evolution of Pt-Ni catalyst during electrochemical potential cycling [109]. Reproduced with permission. In situ transmission electron microscopy and artificial intelligence enabled data analytics for energy materials Hongkui Zheng 1 Xiner Lu 1 Kai He ⁎ Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Clemson University, Clemson 29634, USA Department of Materials Science and Engineering Clemson University Clemson 29634 USA Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Clemson University, Clemson 29634, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. The order of authorship was determined by a coin toss. Graphic abstract The deep synergy of in situ TEM and artificial intelligence-enabled analytics offers unprecedented capabilities for real-time investigation of dynamic behaviors for materials used in energy-related technologies. Energy materials are vital to energy conversion and storage devices that make renewable resources viable for electrification technologies. In situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is a powerful approach to characterize the dynamic evolution of material structure, morphology, and chemistry at the atomic scale in real time and in operando. In this review, recent advancements of in situ TEM techniques for studying energy materials, including catalysts, batteries, photovoltaics, and thermoelectrics, are systematically discussed and summarized. The topics include a broad range of material transformations that are in situ stimulated by heating, biasing, lighting, electron-beam illuminating, and cryocooling under vacuum, liquid, or gas environments within TEM, as well as the mechanistic understanding of the associated solid-solid, solid-liquid, and solid-gas reactions elucidated by in situ TEM examination and operando measurements. Special focus is also put on the emerging progress of artificial intelligence enabled microscopy data analytics, including machine learning enhanced tools for retrieving useful information from massive TEM imaging, diffraction, and spectroscopy datasets, highlighting its merits and potential for automated in situ TEM experimentation and analysis. Finally, the pressing challenges and future perspectives on in situ TEM study for energy-related materials are discussed. Keywords In situ TEM Cryo-TEM Energy materials Batteries Catalysts Photovoltaic Thermoelectric Artificial intelligence Machine learning 1 Introduction Energy is an indispensable foundation for the socioeconomic development of the modern world. The production and consumption of energy have provided fuels to technological advancements and brought inevitable impacts on global climate change [1,2]. The majority of current energy consumption still depends on fossil fuels, which are non-renewable resources and prone to generate pollutants and greenhouse gases to cause serious environmental problems. To satisfy the ultimate requirement of sustainability and energy security, it is desired to transform the traditional energy structure with the low utilization rate to the emerging low-carbon technologies that significantly benefit from the exploitation of renewable and clean energy resources such as solar, wind, geothermal, and ocean energy [3]. The technologies enabling these renewable resources for viable electrification are essentially based on energy conversion and storage devices, including fuel cells, batteries, solar cells, and thermoelectric generators, which further boost the increasing research efforts in advanced materials for catalysts, battery electrodes, photovoltaics, and thermoelectric materials [4–7]. From the materials science standpoint, the fundamental understanding of the structure-property relationship and the evolution of material structure and chemistry at the relevant length and temporal scales are vital and urgent for the rational design of energy-related applications. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is a powerful tool for materials characterization using imaging, diffraction, and spectroscopy techniques with ultra-high resolution [8]. Specifically, high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) is typically used to visualize materials structures on the atomic level, electron diffraction is capable of identifying the crystallography and phase information, and analytical spectroscopy such as energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) can determine the elemental identities, chemical bonds, valence states, and electronic structures as well as their spatial distributions when simultaneously coupled with scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). The groundbreaking development of aberration correctors and monochromators since the 1990s has enabled the unprecedented spatial resolution of ∼0.4 Å [9,10] and energy resolution up to ∼4.2 meV [11], offering utmost capabilities to resolve the structure and chemistry of materials. Advanced TEM-based techniques have been substantially used to characterize various energy materials under the conditions where they are taken from a specific reaction stage or evolving process, which is known as “postmortem” or “ex situ” examination [12]. In contrast, to gain better knowledge of the genuinely intrinsic properties, it is crucial to directly monitor the material transformation on the scene of a live reaction or process, referred to as “in situ” characterization. The concept of in situ TEM is to apply one or multiple physical stimuli (i.e., heat, force, light, electrical bias, magnetic field, electron beam, cooling, etc.) or chemically reactive environments (i.e., gases or liquids) inside the TEM column to mimic the realistic scenarios where the target material is operated or functioned and thus observe the material’s structural, chemical, and functional evolutions in real time. In situ TEM has been a fast-evolving field in the past two decades with tremendous effort devoted to instrumentation development and materials science research [13–15]. In this review, we focus on the applications of in situ TEM for energy conversion and storage materials, specifically including catalysts, batteries, photovoltaic and thermoelectric materials. The topics of interest include materials transformation during chemical and electrochemical reactions or physical processes under vacuum, gas-phase, and liquid-phase environments, in which heating, biasing, electron beam, light, and cryogenic (cryo) stimuli may be applied, either individually or jointly, to the samples through various types of in situ specimen holders (i.e., open cells and closed cells) or column settings (i.e., environmental TEM, ETEM), as illustrated in the schematics in Fig. 1 . With such sophisticated in situ TEM methodologies, real-time imaging, diffraction, and spectroscopy are allowed to directly track the evolution of structural and chemical transformation during dynamic processes or reactions under their working conditions. Artificial intelligence (AI) is a simulation of human intelligence that is introduced into machines to allow them to think and solve problems like human beings [16]. Machine learning (ML) is an application of AI that uses computer algorithms to automatically learn from data and apply the learned knowledge to make decisions, which has been developed to the next-generation deep learning (DL) that executes the learning process independently on human intervention through artificial neural networks [17–19]. In situ TEM is a data-intensive characterization method that generates a vast number of graphic and spectral datasets as a function of time, position, or other experimental parameters. Processing and analyzing these massive datasets are tedious and time-consuming through traditional manual procedures, which may also induce errors due to cognitive bias. Therefore, it is highly desired to use AI-enabled approaches to perform autonomous and objective data analysis for in situ TEM characterization. ML-enhanced methods have recently been applied to microscopy imaging and spectroscopy analyses to address the pressing concerns [20–23]. In this review, we will summarize the recent progress on the emerging AI-enabled analytics for automated processing and interpretation of TEM image, diffraction, and spectroscopy data and specifically emphasize its applications and impact on in situ TEM experiments by highlighting the representative case studies demonstrated in different model systems. We envision that this review will be a useful guidance for audience to choose suitable in situ TEM techniques for their interested topics and provide a comprehensive bibliographic index for in situ TEM technical developments and their applications in energy-related materials research. The content of this review is organized as follows: Section 2 will describe the up-to-date progress of in situ TEM for energy conversion and storage materials, explicitly focusing on catalysts, batteries, photovoltaic and thermoelectric materials, as well as the energy materials that are sensitive to electron beam damage. Section 3 will discuss the recent advancement of AI-enabled data analysis approaches and their applications to process and interpret microscopy images and spectra. Section 4 will provide the concluding remarks along with the pressing challenges and future perspectives to chart a forward-looking path in this field. 2 In situ TEM applications in energy conversion and storage 2.1 In situ TEM for catalysts Catalysis is the cornerstone for chemical and petroleum industries and essential for a wide range of chemical reactions and processes underpinning clean energy and environmental sustainability. The primary key to determining a catalyst’s suitability for a process is critically related to three catalytic properties, i.e., activity, selectivity, and stability, which are essentially dependent on the catalyst’s structure, morphology, and composition [4]. Despite traditional TEM postmortem characterization has played an essential role in revealing the effect of catalysts’ static structures (crystal facets, defects, interfaces, etc.) on catalytic properties at as-synthesized and post-reaction states, it is necessarily vital to uncover the dynamic evolution of the structure-property relationship under the operating conditions and realistic environments using in situ TEM. Depending on different types of catalysis, i.e., thermocatalysis, electrocatalysis, and photocatalysis, in situ TEM can employ various stimuli to trigger the dynamic evolution of catalyst nanoparticle’s crystal growth or initiate the catalytic reactions between solid-solid, solid-liquid, and solid-gas phases. In this section, we have extensively summarized the in situ TEM studies on catalyst materials based on the types of in situ settings, reaction environments, and reactions or processes of interest, as listed in Table 1 . For each category, we selectively choose representative case studies to highlight the development of in situ TEM setup and the scientific progress for the relevant research areas. 2.1.1 In situ heating for solid-state transformation Despite any specific catalytic process, the thermal stability of catalysts has always been a critical concern for both academic research and industrial applications. This is because the catalyst nanocrystals are often treated by thermal annealing to adjust their compositions and surface structures or subject to elevated temperatures under their working scenarios. Therefore, understanding the material transformation pathway and the thermal stability at the relevant temperatures is necessary for the rational design of catalysts. In situ heating is a commonly used function introduced to TEM, which has been developed through several generations with different types of heating sample holders, as shown in Fig. 2 (A–C). The first generation heating holder is the furnace-type holder (Fig. 2A) that can heat the entire 3 mm TEM grid up to ∼1000 °C, which produces a prominent issue of uneven temperature distribution and dramatic thermal drift on the sample. It is also not suitable for EDS analysis because of the strong X-ray shadowing caused by the geometry of the bulk furnace [114]. Fig. 2(B) shows another type of bulk heater made of spiral-shaped tungsten wire (developed by Hitachi), raising the temperature up to ∼1500 °C by the Joule heating through the wire [115]. However, the drawback is that the samples are limited only to the nanostructured materials attached to the unshadowed surface of the wire, largely reducing the visible area and the tilting range. The latest generation heating holder is based on the microelectromechanical system (MEMS) technique, which enables the localized Joule heating via a nanopatterned metal heating element controlled by a four-probe feedback loop [116], as shown in Fig. 2(C). The MEMS-based heating holder offers the precise control of the local temperature up to 1100–1300 °C for both nanostructured and focused ion beam (FIB) samples, as well as larger tilting ranges and better EDS collection. The localized heating of the MEMS technique can rapidly reach the desired temperature (within few milliseconds) and greatly reduce the specimen drift in comparison with the furnace-type holder. Due to the small thermal mass, the heated area only induces a minimal thermal expansion on the local MEMS membrane window, which allows fast drift stabilization within few minutes or less, largely facilitating in situ observations. The MEMS heating chips are typically pre-calibrated by the manufacturer based on the temperature-dependent resistance measurement. However, the actual temperature of local observation area may not necessarily be as accurate as the read-out of the temperature controller due to the electron-beam induced heating effect. For example, the high-energy electron beam of TEM can be used as a local heat source to initiate nanocrystal transformations, though the exact temperature is unable to be directly measured [117]. This effect becomes even more severe when the holder is used in non-vacuum environments with variable gas species and pressures. To minimize the distraction from this effect, precise verification of temperature calibration under real experimental conditions is required, which can be performed using thermometric materials with characteristic transition temperatures (e.g., melting point, crystal phase transition, magnetic transition, thermal expansion of lattice, chemical reaction) or using plasmon/phonon excitations measured by spectroscopy (e.g., EELS) or diffraction methods [118]. In situ heating experiments have been performed inside TEM for many mono- and multi-metallic nanocatalyst systems using different heating holders. Yoshida et al. have used in situ aberration-corrected TEM (AC-TEM) to study the dynamic behavior of Pt nanocrystals induced by the high electron dose of a 300 kV electron beam [27]. Fig. 2(D) shows selected snapshots from the original in situ TEM video, in which the electron beam increases the mobility of Pt atoms to allow them to migrate on the carbon film. As a result, Pt atoms may maintain their positions or move to the adjacent Pt nanoparticle. Such inter-particle transfer of surface atoms between two neighbor nanoparticles of the similar size will eventually result in the shrink of one particle and expansion of the other, known as Ostwald ripening. These observations revealed the mechanism of the Ostwald ripening process with single-atom resolution and suggested that, in addition to the single atom movement, bi-atoms and clusters may also exhibit collective transfer during the Ostwald ripening process [27]. In addition, the dynamic behaviors during nanoparticle migration, coalescence, and sintering processes have also been identified in monometallic Au, Ag, and Pt nanocrystals [24–26]. Bimetallic heterogeneous nanocrystals consisting of both noble metal and transition metal (TM) elements usually exhibit superior catalytic performance to the single noble metal catalysts [119–121]. Nevertheless, the addition of the second constituent brings in extra compositional and structural complexities, leading the bimetallic nanocrystals to different configurations such as ordered intermetallics, random alloy, core-shell, Janus, and so on [121]. Given that the complex structures may change from one form to another upon annealing or operating at elevated temperatures, the catalytic activity and stability would be significantly affected. Therefore, it is crucial to understand these transformation pathways through in situ heating experiments. Pt-Ni nanocrystals are a popular bimetallic system due to their exceptional electrocatalytic activity on the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the fuel cell cathode [122]. Gocyla et al. performed in situ heating TEM study of phase segregated PtNi1.5 octahedral nanocrystals [32]. Fig. 2(E) displays a series of HRTEM images showing the evolution of a Pt-Ni nanoparticle with temperatures ranging from 50 to 500 °C. The pristine Ni-rich Pt-Ni nanoparticle in the concave octahedron shape gradually changes its morphology during the heating process, as illustrated in the schematics. Upon thermal annealing to 200 °C, Pt diffuses from the edges and formes partly filled {111} facets. Further Pt diffusion leads to the formation of the truncated octahedron shape, followed by the cuboctahedron shape due to the increase in {100} surface area at 300 °C, then partly rounded facets at 400 °C and finally to the spherical particle at 500 °C. Throughout the annealing process, the catalysts keep a balance between the Pt shell thickness and the Ni subsurface enrichment and reach an optimized ratio between {111} and {100} facets, which are considered the key to achieving long-term stability and active catalytic performance [32]. Similar studies were also performed in sandwich-type Pt-Ni octahedral nanoparticles [31] and Pt-rich Pt-Ni octahedral nanoparticles [30], further demonstrating the impact of composition redistribution on catalytic performance. Other Pt-TM (TM = Co, Cu, Fe, etc.) bimetallic nanocrystals are also promising electrocatalysts for ORR. Xiong et al. [29] directly visualized the phase transition and morphological change of both fully and partially ordered Pt3Co nanoparticles using in situ atomic-scale STEM and found that the optimal degree of ordering exhibited significantly enhanced durability comparing with the disordered counterpart. Gatalo et al. [33] observed the heat treatment of PtCu3 nanoparticles and found the mechanism of Cu enrichment at elevated temperatures via the migration of Cu single atoms on the carbon support, which is responsible for the morphology reshaping and crystal lattice ordering upon heating to 500 °C. Yao et al. [28] performed in situ heating study of carbon-supported low-Pt alloy catalysts including PtFe3, PtCo3, and PtNi3, which demonstrates that surface enrichment of TM elements may cause faster particle coalescence and induce higher particle mobility on the carbon support, providing guidance to the preparation of thermally stable Pt-alloy catalysts with minimal sintering during thermal annealing. Besides the core-shell and order-disorder evolutions commonly observed in the studies mentioned above, other transformation pathways during thermal annealing may also occur in other heterogeneous catalytic systems. Huang et al. observed the structural transformation of Ag-NiP x core-shell nanocrystals upon thermal treatment using in situ aberration-corrected STEM (AC-STEM) combined with elemental analysis [34]. It was found that the core-shell structure remained stable below 200 °C, then Ag started to diffuse from the core to the surface along with the simultaneous growth of NiP x on the opposite side of Ag, forming an Ag-NiP x Janus structure with a sharp interface, as shown in the high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF)-STEM images in Fig. 2(F). The newly formed Janus structure is relatively stable in the temperature range of 250 to 450 °C, while Ag tends to fully sublimate at 500 °C, forming individual Ni12P5 nanocrystals. It was confirmed that the core-shell to Janus transformation was induced to minimize the surface energy, which provides insights on structural engineering of multicomponent nanocrystals for catalytic applications [34]. In addition, in situ heating TEM has also been widely used to probe the growth mechanisms of many other heterogeneous systems, such as transition metal carbide catalysts Mo2C [35] and W2C [36]. 2.1.2 In situ gas-phase reactions at room and elevated temperatures Injecting gas into the microscope is highly desired to enable solid-gas reactions for in situ TEM, which, however, has to overcome the challenges, including sustaining the high vacuum of the TEM column and mitigating the side effects arising from the scattering of incident electrons with injected gas molecules [74]. There are two general approaches, namely, environmental TEM (ETEM) and closed gas cell, as shown in the schematic illustrations in Fig. 3 (A and C), respectively. ETEM is equipped with a modified column containing a differential pump system, which uses multistage pumps to maintain the pressure difference between the gaseous atmosphere in the objective area and the high vacuum in other parts of the column, separated by the pressure-limiting apertures. A direct advantage is that ETEM allows windowless (open cell) specimen holders with any compatible types of in situ functions and provides a wider range of sample tilting, whereas the shortcoming is the limitation of gas pressure typically less than 10 Torr inside the pole piece gap [123,124]. To address this issue, an alternative approach was pursued to design special in situ TEM holders with gas cell setup, which uses MEMS fabrication to create a closed gas micro-chamber bounded two pieces of silicon chips with thin silicon nitride (SiN x ) membrane windows, allowing the gas flow to reach up to the ambient pressure [125]. The closed gas cell holders are typically integrated with the heating function to enable solid-gas reactions at high temperatures. The gas cell holders are standalone apparatus that can fit compatible microscopes without modification of the TEM column. However, the disadvantages are due to the involvement of SiN x windows, which may reduce the spatial resolution, hamper the acquisition and analysis of EDS/EELS spectra, and limit the sample tilting range. Furthermore, other ancillaries such as gas manifold and quadrupole mass spectrometer systems can also be attached to both ETEM and gas cells to control the composition of inlet gases and detect the species of outlet gases. On the other hand, regardless of open gas cell or TEM setup, attention has to be paid to an inevitable issue arising from the side effect of the electron beam, which may interact with gas molecules and cause unexpected artifacts. It is known that high-energy electron beam can ionize gas molecules through a radiolysis process, making the ionized gas species more reactive than their original states. The beam-induced effects are varied with different gases and electron illumination conditions. Therefore, a common strategy to avoid misleading information is to carry out control experiments to assess such side effects as a function of electron does rate and exposure time. Accordingly, in situ experiments should be conducted at the lowest possible electron dose rate below the pre-determined critical threshold (typically on the order of 100 e− Å−2 s−1). It is also necessary to compare the gas-phase reactions with and without electron beam exposure to ensure valid data interpretation from in situ TEM experiments. Overall, the selection of gas-phase setup and protocol for in situ TEM should base on the balanced consideration of the microscope, holder, and experimental design factors, as well as the electron-beam effect on specific reactions. From the catalysis science perspective, understanding the catalytic behaviors under reactive gas conditions is one of the core questions that can be solved by in situ gas-phase TEM. The solid-gas reactions between catalyst nanocrystals and reactive gases tend to generate modifications in their morphologies, structures, and elemental distributions and thereafter affect the catalytic properties. Recent in situ TEM studies have revealed direct observations of such changes under various oxidation and reduction environments. One exemplary research is the morphology and structure changes of Au nanoparticles supported on CeO2 during CO oxidation reported by Takeda and co-workers [57,74,75]. They have used in situ aberration-corrected ETEM (AC-ETEM) to systematically investigate the morphology change of Au nanoparticles under various CO and O2 mixtures and established the morphology diagram as a function of the partial pressures of CO and O2 in CO/air gaseous mixtures, which implied the tendency to form rounded nanoparticles in O2 and faceted nanoparticles in CO [57]. Further, the team provided direct evidence to visualize the adsorption of CO molecules induced reconstruction of the {100} facets of Au nanoparticles in real space using in situ AC-ETEM [75]. Fig. 3(B) shows the HRTEM images along <110> zone axis of a crystalline Au nanoparticle in the pristine vacuum condition and after the exposure to the CO reaction environment (1 vol% CO in air at 45 Pa). By comparing the corresponding atomic column of the identical regions, it was found that the atoms of the top two {100} layers were reconstructed into the Au {100}-hex surface structure, which was repeatedly observed in CO pressure of 100–2000 Pa and consistent with the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Additional low-voltage AC-ETEM under 80 kV combined with image simulation has confirmed the adsorption of CO molecules on the Au {100}-hex reconstructed surface, which is due to the larger tensile stress and higher surface energy of the {100} facets than the {111} facets. This atomistic model elucidated the Au catalytic mechanisms and the correlation between morphology and catalytic activity of supported Au nanoparticles on CeO2. Recently, He et al. [76] reported a size-dependent order-to-disorder transformation upon CO oxidation reaction of the same supported Au on CeO2 system using in situ ETEM. It is suggested that the vigorously evolving non-rigid nanoparticle structures generate low-coordinated atoms on the perimeter surface and boost the catalytic activity, manifesting size-dependent absorbent-particle interactions and catalytic properties in heterogeneous catalysts. As mentioned above, the alternative gas cell approach has specific advantages over the ETEM to allow reactions to occur at realistic gas pressures and thus has also been applied to study various catalytic behaviors in gas-phase reactions. For example, Pan’s group has recently reported a series of in situ gas cell studies on Pt-based mono-, bi-, and multi-metallic catalysts [43,44,47,62,67]. The in situ TEM observations revealed that the adsorption of CO molecules was attached to the {100} facets of Pt nanoparticles when exposed to 500 Torr 5% CO environment at 423 K, while this surface reconstruction was reversible through the desorption process when the temperature was elevated to 573 K [62]. Later, the surface evolution in ordered Pt3Co nanoparticles was identified by in situ STEM under static pure O2 at 760 Torr [43]. The initial disorder-to-order transition occurred upon oxygen annealing at 720 °C for 30 min, making Pt3Co nanoparticles transform from random alloy phase to intermetallic L12 phase along with the surface Pt segregation to form a two-layer Pt-rich shell. The subsequent oxygen annealing at 300 °C induced the layer-by-layer growth of Pt at (100) surfaces, as evident by the continuous increase of 0.39 nm in the nanoparticle’s diameter (0–64 and 64–128 s) shown in the sequential HAADF-STEM images in Fig. 3(D). It was also found that Co segregation also occurred at the same oxidizing environment, which, however, only took place at the {111} surfaces instead of the {100} surfaces [44]. These experiments have clarified the counter-intuitive oxygen-driven core-shell formation process in Pt3Co and the facet dependence of layer-by-layer growth for Pt and Co elements. Moreover, the team also performed the atomic-resolution observation of the real-time surface elemental distribution and reconstruction trajectories of ternary octahedral Pt2CuNi alloy nanoparticles in an oxidative environment at 300 °C [47]. The results showed that Ni atoms are more susceptible to oxidation than Cu, and they both diffuse to the nanoparticle surface to be oxidized into the NiO x major/CuO x minor surface oxide layers accompanied by surface reconstruction and lattice rearrangement. Overall, the surface segregation can add extra tunability to control the ORR activity of the Pt-based multi-component catalysts. In addition, the combination of both ETEM and gas-cell setups jointly used in the same catalytic reaction system can take advantage of technical merits of both methods and offer reality-relevant complementary information from both imaging and analytical spectroscopy aspects. For example, Zhang et al. [68] recently reported the reversible core-shell structure modification of NiAu bimetallic nanoparticles during CO2 hydrogenation reactions revealed by both ETEM and gas cell approaches. First, ETEM experiments were carried out in the reaction atmosphere at near ambient pressure (9 ± 0.1 mbar, 25% CO2/75% H2) with temperature from 450 to 600 °C and then cooled to 400 °C. The atomic HRTEM identified that Au at the outermost surface dissolved in the Ni matrix to form a mixed NiAu alloy at 600 °C and then reappeared on the surface to form Ni@Au core-shell structure when cooled to 400 °C, which was further verified by both in situ electron diffraction and analytical EELS. Furthermore, the same hydrogenation reaction was repeated in the gas cell reactor under the actual reaction conditions with pressure of one atmosphere (1 bar). Despite the reduced resolution due to the Si3N4 membrane, the reversible alloying/dealloying processes were reproducibly captured by in situ HAADF-STEM observations. This study highlighted the importandce of cross-checking reaction pathways at distinct reaction pressures via ETEM and MEMS gas cells to bridge up the pressure gap between in situ experiments and actual reactions in reality. There are also many in situ atmospheric TEM studies on redox reactions of other standalone or supported noble/transition metal and metal oxide nanoparticles using both ETEM and gas cell approaches. For example, additional in situ ETEM work includes the studies of Au/Pt/Pd/Ag nanoparticles and single atoms [38,39,63–65,77], Ni [41], Co [66], PtCo [45], PtPb@Pt [69], Ba-Ru [70], Au/TiO2 [54–56], Pt/CeO2 [51,52], Pt/Al2O3 [49], Pt/SiO2 [50], Pt/TiO2 [73], Pt@MCM-22 [53], Ni/SiO2 [58], Cu/ZnO [59], MnO x /CeO2 [61], TiO2 [48], Co-doped Pr0.5Ba0.5MnO x [71], Pd/TiO2@C [78] and so on. More in situ gas cell experiments have also been applied to various catalyst systems, such as Pt under H2 and O2 environments [40], Pd under O2 and H2 environments [37], Cu/ZnO in water vapor and Pt/SrTiO3 under H2 [60], Ni under ambient pressure oxygen [42], PtNi under oxidizing (O2) and reducing (H2 and CO) environments [46], PtNi under H2 environment [66], PdZn/ZnO under H2 environment [72] and so on. These different studies have uncovered a variety of changes in morphology (i.e., size, shape), structure (i.e., lattice reconstruction, phase separation), and composition (i.e., elemental redistribution) of different catalysts. Although their reaction mechanisms and evolution pathways may vary from case to case, these studies provide informative benchmarks to enrich our knowledge for developing rational design principles of high-performance catalysts. 2.1.3 In situ electron-beam-induced nanocrystal growth in liquid phase The liquid phase is another major environment for catalytic reactions to take place. In situ liquid cell TEM (LCTEM) has opened the opportunity to visualize the real-time nanocrystal growth in liquid phases. The design of liquid cells incorporated with special sample holders is vital to the development of LCTEM. Due to the high vacuum requirement of TEM, only certain ionic liquids with ultralow vapor pressure may be possibly allowed to the TEM column, which is infeasible to perform LCTEM with desired liquid environments using an open-cell setup. Currently, the viable solution is to enclose the liquid inside a closed-cell through two main setups. The prevailing setup is the MEMS-based liquid cell made by two pieces of windowed Si chip-supported SiN x membranes separated by a sub-micron thick spacer, as shown in the schematics in Fig. 4 (A) [127]. The MEMS liquid cells can accommodate static liquid reservoir and fluid liquid flow as well as micro-electrodes for the simultaneous heating and biasing functions via specialized liquid cell holders that are commercially available on the market. Like the closed gas cells, liquid cells also suffer similar but more severe problems in the deterioration of resolution and analytical capabilities because of extraneous electron scattering with nitride windows and the large volume of liquid along the beam path. The electron beam and aqueous solution interaction also causes unwanted side effects due to radiolysis, etching, bubbling, and charging [128–130]. Due to different vulnerabilities to the high-energy electron beam, liquids tend to suffer from more severe beam-induced side effects than gases, leading to unavoidable decomposition of water into radiolytic products, including hydrated electrons, free radicals (H•, OH•), redox spices (H+, OH−), and gases (H2, O2) [131]. These beam-induced products may change the pH of solution and act as reducing or oxidizing agents to initiate nanocrystal growth and assembly within aqueous solutions, which, however, must be carefully taken into account when studying other targeted chemical or electrochemical reactions. Therefore, the determination of the critical threshold of electron dose rate (typically <10 e− Å−2 s−1) via control experiments is required before conducting in situ liquid-cell TEM to ensure the meaningful explanation of the obtained results. Another setup is the graphene liquid cell that encapsulates small liquid droplets between two layers of graphene sheets, as schematically shown in Fig. 4(C) [80]. Since graphene is the thinnest single-layer material impermeable to liquids, the graphene liquid cell enables unprecedented atomic-level high resolution for LCTEM. Nevertheless, the graphene liquid cell cannot introduce liquid flow or mass transfer from the outside of the cell or integrate electrodes to enable heating, biasing, and electrochemical functions, limiting its application to electron beam induced phenomena within an isolated reaction environment [132]. Because of the strong interaction between the high-energy electron beam and the specimen material, electron beam illumination can induce in situ structural and chemical modifications of solid-state interfaces such as the enhanced strong metal-support interaction in electrocatalytic nanoparticles [133]. Similarly, the electron beam is also considered a functional stimulus to induce the formation and evolution of nanocrystals in liquid environments. Zheng et al. [90] have pioneered a series of in situ LCTEM research using MEMS liquid cells to systematically elucidate the nucleation and growth mechanisms of colloidal nanocrystals in various organic solvent environments. They first studied the crystal growth trajectories of single Pt nanoparticles and discovered two types of growth pathways via either monomer attachment or coalescence to form particles in uniform size [79]; since then, the oriented attachment mechanism has been verified in various crystal systems [84,95,98]. Later, with the improved atomic-resolution LCTEM imaging, they also identified the facet development during the growth of Pt nanocubes in a solvent mixture of oleylamine, oleic acid, and pentadecane [83]. Fig. 4(B) shows the time-sequential TEM images along with the corresponding simulated images of an individual Pt nanocube viewed along the [0 1 - 1] zone axis. At the early stage of growth, all three low-index facets (i.e., {100}, {110}, and {111}) have a similar growth rate until they reach a limit subsequentially for {100} and then {110} facets. The continued growth of {111} facets eventually transformed the nanoparticle into a faceted nanocube. Combining with DFT calculations of surface energies and ligand binding energies, the study revealed the ligand mobility-controlled selective facet-arrested shape evolution mechanism. Further, this team uncovered the crystal growth and shape evolution of Pt3Fe nanowires through the end-to-end nanoparticle attachment [89]. Such self-assembled particle chain formation processes involve the monomer attachment, straightening, orientation correction, and mass redistribution, which was attributed to the dipolar interaction between nanoparticles. It was also found that the formed Pt3Fe nanowires tend to breakdown into larger particles with a relatively low concentration of oleylamine (20%), while remain stable when the concentration of oleylamine increased to 30%, which highlights the important role of organic solvent in controlling the size and shape of the nanocrystals [90]. Graphene liquid cell was firstly demonstrated by Yuk et al. to study the colloidal growth of Pt nanoparticles with superior atomic resolution [80]. They found that coalescence is a facet-selective process along the lowest surface energy {111} crystallographic planes to develop the oriented attachment with two distinct structures: (1) a perfectly aligned crystal with a single crystallographic domain, or (2) a twinned nanoparticle with {111} mirrored double domains. Fig. 4(D) shows the real-time evolution of the latter coalescence pathway viewed along the [011] zone axis, indicating that the initial misoriented particle attachment gives rise to the twin boundary formation (red dotted line), and the surface rearrangement is the main mechanism for the nanoparticle growth. Later, the same group developed a new method by taking advantage of freely rotating Pt nanoparticles in the solution of graphene liquid cell to reconstruct the 3D features at a near-atomic resolution [81], further pushing the boundary to enable dynamic tracking of 3D structural evolution of nanostructures in solutions. Apart from graphene, other atomic-thin 2D films can also be used for the same purpose. For example, De Clercq et al. [86] used a modified graphene oxide liquid cell to study the real-time growth of Pt-Pd nanoparticles in organic solvents, in which the preparation and manipulation of graphene oxide were considered easier than the use of pure graphene. Recently, Yang et al. [82] developed a modified graphene-MoS2 liquid cell using 2D MoS2 as a functional substrate as well as the membrane window (covered by graphene on the top) for LCTEM to enable a facile and polymer-free MoS2 transfer process, which offers a unique platform to study the nanoparticle-substrate epitaxy and interaction. Besides the selected case studies described above, many other LCTEM studies have been reported in the literature on the topics including, but not limited to, the following. As for the heterogeneous growth for complex nanoparticle structures, Jungjohann et al. [87] made use of electron beam induced reduction reaction to grow Au-Pd core-shell nanostructures, showing that different sizes of the core caused a strongly dependent thickness variation of the Pd shell; Liang et al. [91] revealed the growth of Fe3Pt-Fe2O3 core-shell nanoparticles via initial formation and growth of the Fe-Pt alloy core followed by the epitaxial growth of Fe2O3 shell under electron beam irradiation; Wu et al. [88] reported the core-shell growth of Au@Pt icosahedral nanoparticles, clarifying the kinetically controlled diffusion of Au from corner islands to terraces and edges. Similarly, in situ LCTEM has also been used to investigate various heterogeneous nanoparticles such as Ag-Pd nanocages [85], core-shell PtNi-Ni nanoparticles [92], 2D transition metal oxide nanosheets [94], spinel ferrite nanoparticles [93], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [96] and so on. As for the real-time tracking of nanoparticle movement, interaction, and assembly in liquids, Park et al. [97] reported the superlattice formation of Pt nanoparticles driven by capillary forces and solvent fluctuations under electron-beam irradiation; Powers et al. [104] tracked the self-assembly trajectories of PtFe3 nanoparticles to form a loosely packed hcp lattice driven long-range anisotropic magnetic forces and short-range van der Waals interactions; Niu et al. [103] identified the coalescence of Bi nanoparticles through both symmetric and asymmetric coalescence mechanisms; Chen et al. [99–102] explored the polymeric and DNA-conjugated self-assembly dynamic of various nanostructures in liquids. As for other new aspects, Yin et al. [105] used the electron beam as a “light” source to initiate the pseudo-photocatalytic reaction of TiO2 nanorods for water splitting applications. These studies have demonstrated the versatile implementations of LCTEM coupled with electron beam as a triggering stimulus, which will continue to advance new knowledge related to nanocrystals for catalysis. 2.1.4 In situ electrochemical biasing for liquid-phase reactions There has been an increasing interest in studying catalyst materials under electrochemical working conditions. One specific focus is to study nanoparticle’s electrocatalytic activity for the ORR at the cathode of fuel cells. MEMS-based liquid cells provide a viable platform to integrate the electrical biasing function to a sealed solution system and apply an electrochemical potential to operate catalysts for cycling, during which the dynamic evolution of catalysts can be captured by TEM imaging and cyclic voltammetry (CV) can be simultaneously measured. Using this electrochemical liquid cell technique, some early studies became possible to perform. For example, Zhu et al. [108] observed the structural evolution of Pt-Fe nanoparticles under electrochemical bias in the native perchloric acid (HClO4) electrolyte environment and found that the coarsening processes are non-uniform in both space and time scale, with the growth rate depending on both site and potential. Kato [106] modified the design of MEMS sample holder by reducing the liquid cell thickness to reach higher resolution and thereafter distinguished the migration and aggregation of neighboring small Pt nanoparticles during the degradation process. Recently, Beermann et al. [109] investigated the time-resolved degradation pathways of carbon-supported Pt-Ni alloy catalysts during cycling and startup/shutdown conditions. Fig. 5 (A) shows a series of HAADF-STEM images during cyclic potential sweeps between 0.0 and +1.0 VRHE. It was found that the large Ni-rich particle marked by the arrow started to dissolve after 10 cycles, which continuously diminished with only a small fraction retained after 15 cycles and completely disappeared after 40 cycles. Meanwhile, the particle became less dense, spongy, and porous throughout the entire process. The degradation of octahedral Pt-Ni alloy catalysts, including particle shape shrinkage, agglomeration, corrosion of carbon support, and dissolution of Ni nanoparticles, was clarified to be strongly affected by the cycling potential and holding time. Another recent study by Impagnatiello et al. [107] utilized the energy-filtered TEM (EFTEM) coupled with the LCTEM setup to improve the resolution (<1 nm) for monitoring the degradation of Pt nanoparticle catalysts at the sub-10 nm scale. Fig. 5(B) shows the evolution of individual Pt nanoparticles in different regions where the degradation processes occurred with the increasing number of CVs. The orange boxes (b1–b3) show the detachment of a Pt nanoparticle from the carbon support, which was invisible after 150 CVs but occurred 200 CVs. The garnet boxes (c1–c3) show the coalescence of three Pt nanoparticles, which merged into a larger particle after 200 CVs. The purple boxes (d1–d3) show the appearance of a new Pt nanoparticle through a nucleation-growth process to precipitate within the electrolyte/ionomer phase after 200 CVs. The direct correlation of the structural evolution with the simultaneous CV measurements in this work also provided deeper insights into the catalyst degradation mechanisms in operando conditions. Overall, the research of electrochemical LCTEM has just emerged, and more investigations are anticipated in the future. 2.1.5 In situ light-induced reactions in liquid phase Hydrogen fuel is clean energy that has gained increased attention to address global warming issues. Photocatalytic water splitting is a promising approach to convert the inexpensive renewable water resource into hydrogen using a catalyst and sunlight [134]. To probe the structure-property-performance relationship of photocatalysts using TEM, a photochemical liquid cell has to be made to introduce light as the mandatory stimulus. This can be achieved by incorporating optical fiber into the objective polepieces inside the TEM column [135]. Using this setup, Yoshida et al. [110] studied the photocatalytic behavior of TiO2 under ultraviolet (UV) light irradiation in ionic liquid as the reaction solvent. It was found that ∼8 nm Au nanoparticles were generated from gold cations in the ionic liquid through the photodeposition process after 3 h UV irradiation. Crozier and co-workers [111] modified an ETEM system to introduce high-intensity broadband light illumination using a brass tube supporting optical fiber, as shown in Fig. 6 (A). They investigated the surface change of anatase TiO2 nanocrystals, with the atomic resolution for the first time, under water vapor conditions relevant to the photocatalytic splitting of water. The sequential TEM images in Fig. 6(A) show the surface evolution of anatase TiO2 nanoparticles under 1430 mW/cm2 illumination and varied exposure time to water vapor. The pristine surface was smooth and highly crystalline, which started to become disordered after 1 h exposure to water, then became more pronounced with the increase of exposure time. After 40 h, the top monolayer of each surface turned into amorphous, which contains the Ti3+ oxidation state, as confirmed by EELS analysis. This amorphous layer results from direct photoreaction with water and remains stable without increase in thickness even after prolonged exposure to reaction conditions. Nevertheless, it is noted that the water vapor environments still have discrepancies with the realistic aqueous reaction conditions of water splitting. Recently, Lu et al. [112] employed liquid ETEM coupled with an optical fiber to allow a photochemical cell in a genuine water environment under UV illumination, as shown in Fig. 6(B). They used this setup to study the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction occurring on the surface of anatase TiO2 nanoparticles in water. The time-sequential TEM images in Fig. 6(B) show the formation of bubbles (marked by red arrows) around the nanoparticles after 18 h UV exposure, which continues to grow up to 24 h. In addition, a surface shell was formed on each TiO2 nanoparticles at a rate of ∼0.7 nm/h before the generation of hydrogen bubbles (indicated by green arrows). It was confirmed that the hydrogenated surface shell on TiO2, even without the aid of metal co-catalyst, would promote hydrogen generation by reducing the activation energy needed for H–H bond formation. Yu et al. [113] utilized a modified LCTEM holder with an optical fiber to perform in situ observation of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution on Cu2O in an aqueous solution. It was found that Cu2O cubes can self-reduce to nano-Cu during photocatalytic hydrogen evolution driven by the accumulation of photogenic electrons. Further quantification indicated that the degree of Cu2O self-reduction at active sites ({111}>{110}>{100}) was highly matched with the photocatalytic hydrogen production rate. Generally speaking, the complexity of light-coupled LCTEM setup has limited the in situ photocatalytic and photochemical investigations; however, with continued efforts and mature methodologies, the future of this field is encouraging. 2.2 In situ TEM for batteries Batteries are important energy storage devices that convert chemical energy to electricity as the power supply for other electrical units. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are the predominant rechargeable energy storage technology that has been widely used in portable electronics, electric vehicles, and power systems [5]. To meet the increasing demand of high energy density, safe, and long-lasting energy storage requirements, advanced materials are essentially needed to develop high-performance battery components, including anodes, cathodes, and electrolytes, as well as to enable new battery chemistries used for Li-S, Li-air, and all-solid-state batteries [136]. The knowledge obtained from Li-batteries will also be leveraged to develop the next-generation beyond-Li batteries that use sodium, potassium, magnesium, calcium, aluminum, and zinc ions to store and transfer energy [137]. In situ TEM has been extensively used to probe morphological, structural, and chemical evolutions of battery materials in solid, liquid, and gas environments, aiming to solve critical problems such as reaction (lithiation, sodiation, potassiation, etc.) mechanisms and pathways, interfacial stability and failure modes (Li dendrites, solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), etc.), thermal degradation (oxygen release, thermal runaway, etc.) and so on. Based on in situ TEM setup and specific research focus, we summarize the previous in situ TEM studies of battery materials, as listed in Table 2 . We will selectively choose representative case studies from each category to describe the technical development and the scientific progress in relevant research areas. 2.2.1 In situ electrochemical biasing for solid-state reactions According to the mechanisms of Li-ions storage in the host materials, LIB electrodes can be classified as intercalation, alloying, and conversion materials [329]. The nature of these reaction mechanisms, in turn, determines how much ion insertion can be accommodated in the host lattice (i.e., specific capacity) and how much structural distortion or reorganization can be identified by TEM (i.e., distinguishable features and contrast). It is commonly understood that the alloying and conversion reactions are typically easy to detect due to significant morphology changes. In contrast, the intercalation reaction is often hard to identify as the lattice alteration is merely subtle. Since the first invention of in situ electrochemical nano-cell for TEM by Huang et al. [178], rapid progress has been made in instrumentation design, leading to three types of in situ open-cell setups, as shown in Fig. 7 (A). These setups share a large similarity in their key components: the electrode materials mounted on a stationary sample stage, the Li-source mounted on a moveable probe, and the potentiostat/galvanostat to apply potential/current between the stage and the probe; while the difference lies in the type of electrolytes and the format of target electrode materials. The moveable probe is a crucial component that can be realized via special TEM holders with high-precision piezoelectric motion modules, which are available through commercial vendors like Nanofactory Instruments, Hummingbird Scientific, and ZepTools. The type (i) setup is in a full-cell configuration, consisting of a realistic cathode (i.e., LiCoO2), ultralow vapor pressure ionic liquid electrolyte (ILE), and the target material, which is ideal for studying anode materials in the form of long nanowire geometry. Huang et al. [178] used this setup to perform the first in situ lithiation study of SnO2 nanowires, as shown in Fig. 7(B). The long length (>15 μm) of SnO2 nanowire makes it easy to immerse the tip inside the ILE and creates a good geometry to visualize the dynamic reaction front movement. The time-sequential TEM images show that the pristine straight SnO2 nanowire becomes curved and elongated continuously as the lithiation initiated from the SnO2-ILE interface and produces large volume expansion. After the entire charging process, the nanowire has increased ∼60% in length, ∼45% in diameter, and ∼240% in total volume expansion. The overall lithiation of SnO2 follows consecutive two-step reactions SnO2 → Li2O + Sn → Li x Sn (0 ≤ x ≤ 4.4). The first conversion step induces the amorphization along with the dislocation cloud, and the following alloying step reversibly converts the reduced Sn nanoparticles into Li x Sn alloy nanoparticles. The consecutive conversion-alloying reaction pathway was also identified in ZnO [188–193] and applicable to the sodiation of these materials as well [183,191]. Both the type (ii) and type (iii) setups are in half-cell configurations because they use Li (or another alkali) metal as the anode versus the target material (analog to a half coin cell) and native lithium oxides/nitrides formed on the surface of Li metal as the solid electrolyte (Fig. 7A). These setups are more suitable for studying solid-state reactions since the use of ILE is intentionally excluded to eliminate unwanted side reactions. There are differences in how the target material is loaded on the sample stage and connected with the Li anode. In type (ii) setup, nanoparticles are bonded directly to a metal rod on the sample stage, allowing Li connection and TEM field-of-view only at the stick-out region. In type (iii) setup, nanoparticles are loaded directly onto a TEM half-grid to enable them to connect to Li metal direct on the edge of the grid or through the carbon film supported by the grid, which can mimic the carbon binder on the current collector and leave a much larger field-of-view for TEM observation. Fig. 7(C) shows an exemplary study by Liu et al. [168] that utilized the type (ii) setup to investigate the lithiation of alloying-type Si nanoparticles of different sizes, which were directly dispersed on a tungsten rod. The time-sequential TEM images show the morphological evolution of a 160 nm Si nanoparticle during lithiation, which follows a shell-to-core reaction pathway without showing any cracks throughout the entire process. Systematic analysis on the morphological change as a function of nanoparticle size further revealed the size-dependent fracture behavior for lithiation of Si nanoparticles—when particle size is above the critical value of ∼150 nm, surface cracking and particle fracture would occur. This work provided a fundamental understanding of mechanical failure mechanisms and implications of nanomerization strategy to enhance cycling stability for alloying-type anode materials, including Si [162–168], Al [169], Ge [170], Sn [171], Sb [172–174], and P [176,177]. Fig. 7(D) displays a showcase of the type (iii) setup used for studying the in situ electrochemical reactions with Li, Na, and K. Using this method, He and co-workers [267] have recently performed a systematic and comparative study on the lithiation, sodiation, and potassiation of 2D van der Waals (vdW) layered Bi2Te3 nanoplate. The series of in situ TEM/STEM images show the dynamic structural evolutions of individual Bi2Te3 nanoplates, leading to different reacted and unreacted regions separated by the reaction fronts (indicated by dashed lines), in which the conversion reaction was the predominant process to cause phase separation. It was found that both lithiation and sodiation follow the two-step conversion-alloying route while potassiation proceeds via the three-step intercalation-conversion-alloying route; the latter route has been widely identified as a common reaction pathway in other 2D vdW metal chalcogenides [256–267]. Quantitative measurements of reaction areas as a function of time further indicate that the sodiation exhibits the highest reaction speed among three alkali-ion reactions, consistent with the anomalous high-rate performance of the Na-ion battery (NIB). This unexpected superior Na reaction kinetics was attributed to the higher electro-chemo-mechanical stress concentrated at the sodiation reaction front of the concave shape, comparing to those convex reaction fronts of lithiation and potassiation. The stress-induced enhancement of reaction kinetics and stability was also found in other metal oxide and sulfide systems [194,195,235], which offers insights into the optimization of ionic diffusion kinetics and rate capability through strain engineering. Besides the above case studies of alloying- and conversion-dominant electrodes, the intercalation materials used in commercial rocking-chair batteries have also been extensively studied by in situ TEM, despite the difficulties in identifying their typically unnoticeable structural changes. For anode materials, graphite and the related carbon derivatives have been examined for use in Li/Na/K-ion batteries [138,139]. For example, few-layer graphene nanoribbons [140] and bilayer graphene sheets [141,142] have been studied for their Li diffusion and structural modifications in LIBs; expanded graphite [143], reduced graphene oxides [144], graphene platelets [145], and soft carbon [146] have been studied for their sodiation mechanisms in NIBs; carbon nanofibers [147] have been studied for their microstructure evolution and mechanical degradation during sodiation and potassiation processes. Moreover, Ti-based oxides such as TiO2 [149,150], Li4Ti5O12 [151,152], and Li2TiSiO5 [153] have been studies as alternative zero/low-strain anodes for LIBs. For cathode materials, the popular layered, spinel, and polyanion oxides, including LiCoO2 [154], LiNi1− x − y Mn x Co y O2 (NMC) [155], LiMn2O4 [156–158], and LiFePO4 [159–161], have been carefully studied for the mechanistic understanding of their phase transition, structural evolution, and degradation mechanism in LIBs. These studies have provided useful guidance for optimizing the performance and stability of electrode materials in real-world battery applications. It is also worth noting that the knowledge about the real-time reaction pathways during electrochemical processes can be uniquely provided by in situ TEM. Depending on the specific groups of electrode materials in alkali-ion batteries, they may exhibit distinct reaction pathways that involve single or multiple steps of the intercalation, alloying, and conversion processes. In addition to the simple intercalation and alloying materials undertaking the straightforward one-step intercalation and alloying reactions (Table 2), conversion-type materials show a large variation in their reaction pathways [330]. For example, the compounds (typically metal oxides, chalcogenides, and fluorides) without any alkali-ion-accommodatable interstitial vacancies in their crystal lattices would simply exhibit one-step direct conversion reaction, such as NiO [194–197], Fe2O3 [198], CuO [199–203], Co9S8 [230,231], Co3S4 [232], CoS2 [233], Ni3S2 [234], FeS2 [232,235], FeS [236], FeSe [237], Cu2S [232,238], PbSe [239], FeF2 [274–277], NiF2 [278], Cu x Fe1− x F2 [279], and Co x Fe1− x OF [280]. The metal oxides and chalcogenides with lattice opening (typically tetrahedron and octahedron) would possibly have an intercalation step at the beginning and lead to the two-step intercalation-conversion reaction pathways, such as Fe3O4 [204–208], Co3O4 [209–215], NiCo2O4 [216], MnFe2O4 [217], ZnFe2O4 [218], MnO2 [219–224], RuO2 [225,226], CeO2 [227], WO3 [228], MoO3 [229], TiS2 [240–242], CuS [243,244], MoS2 [245–254], MoSe2 [255], Sb2S3 [268], Sb2Se3 [269], Sb2Te3 [270], NbSe3 [271], WS2 [272], and ReS2 [273]. For those compounds with Sn, Zn, and Bi cations that can alloy with Li, they would consequently experience an extra alloying reaction and thus follow the two-step conversion-alloying reaction pathways for SnO2 [178–187] and ZnO [188–192] and the three-step intercalation-conversion-alloying reaction pathways for SnS2 [256–262], SnS [263], SnCoS2 [264], SnSe2 [265], Bi2S3 [266], and Bi2Te3 [267]. It is also noteworthy that such multi-step pathways may be altered by reaction kinetics related to electrolytes and potential windows in realistic electrochemical conditions. These in situ TEM studies have thoroughly elucidated the crystal structure and redox reaction-dependent reaction pathways, which is essential for understanding and optimizing the electrode materials’ electrochemical properties and stabilities for next-generation battery applications. Along with the investigations of electrode materials alone, there has been increasing interest in studying structures and properties of the solid-state electrode-electrolyte interfaces in full-cell batteries using in situ TEM. For this purpose, another two types of in situ open-cell setups (i.e., types iv and v) have been developed to build nanoscale batteries in the full-cell configuration, as shown in Fig. 8 (A). The type (iv) setup is adapted from the above moveable-probe setups, and the full-cell battery sample is directly cut from thin-film batteries and fabricated using the FIB lift-out technique. Using this setup, Meng and co-workers [284] made a nanoscale full cell from the thin-film all-solid-state battery (ASSB) consisting of layer-by-layer deposited LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode, lithium phosphorus oxynitride (LiPON) solid-state electrolyte (SSE), and Si anode, as shown in Fig. 8(B). The STEM-EELS method was used to map out the Li concentration across the LCO/LiPON interface at pristine, as well as ex situ and in situ charged states. It was found that a disordered interfacial layer composed of rock-salt structured Li2O and CoO is formed between LCO and LiPON, which leads to the higher Li-ion concentration after the charging process, as confirmed by ex situ and in situ samples. These findings provide direct evidence for the chemical evolution at the LCO/LiPON interface to reveal the associated degradation mechanism. Another type of in situ full cells can be achieved by the setup (v), which uses the FIB method to fabricate a nanoscale full-cell battery sample onto a MEMS chip fitting in an in situ biasing holder (Fig. 8A). In this setup, the battery sample can be cut from a thin-film ASSB as mentioned above (Fig. 8D) or manufactured by assembling each component using FIB (Fig. 8C) and then tested inside TEM under working conditions identical to real batteries. Using this setup, Gong et al. [285] built a full-cell ASSB consisting of LCO cathode, Li6.75La2.84Y0.16Zr1.75Ta0.25O12 (LLZO, note: undoped standard formula Li7La3Zr2O12) electrolyte, and Au anode, as shown in Fig. 8(C). They used both HAADF-STEM and angular bright-field (ABF)-STEM imaging to identify the crystal structures of LCO after the delithiation process and found that the pristine LCO single crystal was transformed into polycrystalline LCO but only in two kinds of crystal orientations separated by coherent twin boundaries (between the same orientation) or antiphase domain boundaries (between different orientations). Such nanopolycrystallization phenomenon may change the contact between electrode and electrolyte and thereafter affect the Li diffusion during the delithiation process. Later, this group used the same method to make the LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 (LNMO)/LLZO/Au full-cell battery and studied its atomic structure evolution in three dimensions along the <100>, <110>, <111>, and <112> zone axes [290]. It was found that the ordered to disordered structural evolution occurs along <100>, <110>, and <111> zone axes, and inhomogeneous structural evolution takes place along <112> zone axis, resulting in TM-rich regions, antiphase boundary regions, and TM migration-front regions after delithiation. Nomura et al. [291] reported a recent work to study the Li transfer resistance in bulk-type ASSBs using the full cell made of Ni-rich layered oxide Li x Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 (NCA) cathode, sulfide-based 75Li2S − 25P2S5 (LPS) glass-ceramic electrolyte, and in metal anode, as shown in Fig. 8(D). The operando STEM-EELS spectrum imaging was used to reveal the dynamic Li-ion diffusion in NCA secondary particles (visible in the color image series) under low- and high-rate charge-discharge reaction conditions. Combined with additional analysis of the crystal orientation mismatch between different particles using 4D STEM, it was demonstrated that the Li diffusion through nanocrystal grain boundaries is the primary limiting factor for Li conduction in particle cathodes, which suggests the strategy to optimize the interfacial structure and nanocrystal orientation for the enhancement of high-rate capability of ASSBs. Besides these exemplary case studies demonstrated through cathode-electrolyte interfaces, there are also several studies carried out on diverse cathode/SSE interfaces such as LCO/Li6PS5Cl [289], LCO/LASGTP [286–288], MNC76/LLTO [155], and Li/SSE interfaces such as Li/LLZO [293] and Li/LiPON [294], Li/Li3PS4 [292], Li/LAGP [295] and Li/LATP [296] (also see Table 2). These in situ TEM studies have manifested the universal feasibility of the full-cell setup and provided tremendous new knowledge regarding the most promising solid-state electrolytes under active development. The aforementioned five types of in situ open-cell setups provide versatile capabilities to study solid-state reactions in various battery materials and devices. The appropriate selection of in situ setups to solve a desired material question should specifically consider the sample structure, geometry, and the electrochemical configuration. As a general guidance, setups (i)–(iii) are used to study active electrode materials of different geometries: specifically, setup (i) for one-dimensional nanowires/fibers/tubes with high aspect ratio, setup (ii) for nanomaterials and their assemblies with the lateral size of few-hundred nanometer to few micrometer that allow easy contact to the movable biasing probe, and setup (iii) for generic nanomaterials directly dispersed onto a carbon-supported TEM grid. These settings are typically in the half-cell configuration with direct contact to alkali metals, except when ionic liquid is used in setup (i). In contrast, setups (iv) and (v) provide additional capabilities to study solid-state electrode and electrolyte materials as well as their interfaces within a nano/micro-scale battery device in format of half-cell, full-cell, or symmetric-cell configurations. The MEMS settings in setup (v) could offer more precise operando measurements of electrochemical properties than the single-point contact approach used in other setups, although the device fabrication is more sophisticated. 2.2.2 In situ electrochemical biasing for liquid-phase reactions The electrochemical reactions of battery materials in liquid-phase environments are essentially relevant to real-world LIBs, in which organic liquid electrolytes are generally used and interacted with electrodes to generate SEI formation and Li dendrite growth. In situ LCTEM is an ideal tool to create a more relevant environment to study solid-liquid reactions under realistic electrochemical biasing conditions. In 2013, Gu et al. [303] reported the first demonstration of an operando electrochemical LCTEM using the MEMS-based liquid cell setup, as shown in the schematics in Fig. 9 (A). The single Si nanowire is the active working electrode while Li metal works as the counter electrode; they both are connected to the Pt electrodes on the MEMS chip and fully immersed in the lithium perchlorate (LiClO4) in ethylene carbonate (EC)-dimethyl carbonate (DMC) electrolyte to make a closed circuit. The liquid-cell battery was operated in potentiostatic and galvanostatic modes for charge/discharge cycles. The lithiation process occurred conformally at the entire nanowire and caused anisotropic expansion along the <110> direction. The delithiation process reversibly occurred when voltage was 0.45 V vs. Li/Li+ and induced diameter shrinkage from 195 to 92 nm. Comparing to the open-cell lithiation/delithiation of Si nanowires, the morphologies before and after reactions are almost the same, but the reaction path differs from the linear propagation (from one end to the other) in the open cell to the conformal propagation in the liquid cell (from surface to core). Since the SEI plays a critical role in battery capacity and stability, probing SEI formation mechanism and composition remains urgent. Zheng and co-workers [297] have used the in situ electrochemical LCTEM to demonstrate a proof-of-concept for visualizing the SEI formation during electrochemical lithiation and delithiation of Au anodes in a commercial LiPF6/EC/DEC (diethyl carbonate) electrolyte. It was found that the inhomogeneous electrolyte decomposition, SEI formation, and Li dendritic growth occurred during the lithiation of Au in the realistic LIB setting. Several other studies on similar model systems (Au/Pt anode in commercial organic electrolytes) have reproduced the SEI formation and Li dendritic growth on the anode surface and provided more insights into understanding the underlying mechanisms [298–302]. Furthermore, such in situ LCTEM investigation was also extended to other realistic systems, such as in LiFePO4 in aqueous electrolyte [306] and MoS2 in LiPF6/EC/DEC electrolyte [307]. Holtz et al. [306] tracked the Li transfer using elastic energy-filtered TEM (EFTEM) and determined the lithiation state of LiFePO4 electrode and surrounding aqueous electrolyte using valence EELS during multiple charge-discharge cycles. Zeng et al. [307] revealed the dissolution and deformation of MoS2 during lithiation and, more importantly, identified the composition of the SEI layer using EDS and nanobeam diffraction, which contains C, O, and F species along with LiF nanocrystals. Graphene liquid cell was also used for in situ electrochemical experiments in the liquid phase. Yuk et al. [304] first used the graphene liquid cell to study the lithiation of Si nanoparticles in the LiPF6/EC/DMC/DEC electrolyte, which revealed the anisotropic volume expansion along <110> directions due to smaller energy barrier and demonstrated its feasibility as a general approach for solid-liquid reactions in LIBs. Most recently, Zhang et al. [308] adapted the same concept of the graphene liquid cell but modified the setup using carbon film supported TEM half-grid with low vapor pressure ILE to make a functional cell for operando TEM characterization of spinel structured Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) anode, as shown in Fig. 9(B). They performed the operando Li K-edge EELS to the Li+ transport in LTO during the discharge and charge cycles, which shows that the main peak of Li K-edge remains the same whereas the pre-edge peaks “S” (related to stable Li occupancy configurations in Li4Ti5O12 and Li7Ti5O12) and “M” (related to metastable Li occupancy configurations of the intermediate LTO compositions) vary as a function of the state of charge and the charge rate. With the help of DFT calculation, the facile Li+ migration routes were revealed in intermediate configurations involving face-sharing Li polyhedral at a high rate, which provides insights into designing electrode materials for fast-charging LIBs. Overall, in situ LCTEM has been demonstrated to be a feasible and effective method to study the electrode-electrolyte reactions and the associated morphological and chemical evolutions at the nanoscale. With the continued technical advancement, it is expected that in situ electrochemical LCTEM can provide more information on the atomistic level. 2.2.3 In situ electrochemical biasing for gas-phase reactions Rechargeable metal-air batteries hold great promise for the next-generation energy storage technologies due to the higher energy density than traditional LIBs. So far, several types of metal-air batteries have been studied, such as Li-air, Na-air, K-air, Zn-air, Fe-air, Mg-air, and Al-air batteries [331]. For a functional metal-air battery, the air cathode is required to efficiently catalyze both ORR and the reversible oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Although the knowledge obtained from alkaline fuel cells can be readily translated to metal-air batteries, some critical questions remain elusive in metal-air battery settings, such as the formation mechanisms of metal superoxides and peroxides. In this regard, in situ gas-phase TEM presents a unique approach to study the electrochemical solid-gas reactions in metal-air batteries. The first demonstration work was performed by Wang and co-workers in 2017 using the ETEM approach [309]. They adapted the type (ii) open-cell setup to build a functional Li-O2 battery using carbon nanotubes coated with RuO2 catalysts as a cathode, Li metal as an anode, and Li2O formed on the surface of Li metal as a solid electrolyte. The cell was exposed to the 0.1 mbar oxygen-gas environment inside an ETEM, as schematically shown in Fig. 10 (A). It was found that the discharge and charge of the solid-state Li-O2 battery produce the reversible formation of hollow spherical particles, including the continued expansion of the hollow sphere during the ORR (0–72 s) and the subsequent shrinkage to a crumpled shell during the OER (0–192 s), as indicated by the time-resolved HAADF-STEM images. The ORR experiences two-step oxidation and disproportionation chemical reactions (O2 + Li+ + e– → LiO2 → Li2O2 + O2) to form Li2O2 with the release of O2, while the OER follows a two-step decomposition (Li2O2 → LiO2 → O2) to release O2 gas. Recently, another work on Li-O2 battery was performed using the same in situ ETEM method, which demonstrated the use of LiTaO3 coated nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube as a cathode to improve the electrochemical reaction kinetics, enabling fast Li-ion transport on the cathode side [310]. These studies have provided valuable insights into understanding the catalytic reduction and evolution reaction mechanisms in Li-air batteries. Na-O2 batteries have also been studied using in situ ETEM by Huang et al. [311–313] and Gu et al. [314,315] in the past few years. Fig. 10(B) shows an exemplary case study using Au-coated MnO2 as the cathode to facilitate the ORR and OER in Na-O2 batteries [311]. The HAADF-STEM combined with electron diffraction and EELS analysis revealed the bubble-like NaO2 formation after ORR, followed by rapid disproportionation into Na2O2 and O2, causing ∼18 × volume expansion on the surface of Au-coated MnO2 nanowire. However, it was interesting to note that no ORR reaction occurred at the bare MnO2 nanowire, and the corresponding Na+ intercalation only induced 217% increase of the nanowire, which proves the effect of Au-catalyzed oxygen chemistry in the Na-O2 battery. Other studies done by these two groups further confirmed the electrocatalytic effect of Co3O4 [313], Ag [312], CuS [314], Pt and Pt-Ir [315] on promoting the ORR and OER processes in Na-O2 batteries. Recently, a study of K-O2 batteries using in situ ETEM has also been reported by Huang’s group [316]. In this work, a single α-MnO2 nanowire was used as the cathode of the K-O2 battery and exposed in 1 mbar O2 gas inside ETEM. Fig. 10(C) shows the HRTEM images and electron diffraction patterns obtained during the discharge in an O2 environment, revealing the reaction front movement and associated phase evolution during the conversion and ORR reactions. The first reaction front was identified as the boundary between pristine MnO2 and converted Mn3O4 and K2O (3MnO2 + 4 K++4e−→Mn3O4 + 2K2O), while the second reaction front was bounded with the ORR products of MnO and K2O (Mn3O4 + 2 K++2e−→3MnO + K2O) along with the formation of localized cracks. This two-step reaction mechanism clarified the superoxide chemistry in the K-O2 battery and provided insights for the design of new K-O2 battery materials in the future. 2.2.4 In situ heating for solid-state transformations in cathodes Layered TM oxides are among the most promising cathode materials for LIBs, which inevitably suffer from mechanical cracking, TM leaching, oxygen degassing, and other failures upon prolonged cycling [332]. Temperature rise, especially localized overheat, is a ubiquitous phenomenon in batteries, which may likely trigger structural degradation and subsequent thermal runaways to cause severe safety problems. In situ heating TEM is a powerful tool that can offer thermal stimulus to study temperature-dependent degradation and failure mechanisms through real-time and high-resolution observations to understand and address this issue fundamentally. LiCoO2 (LCO) is a mature cathode material widely used in commercial LIBs. The thermal degradation mechanism of LCO has been revealed by in situ heating TEM done by Shahbazian-Yassar and co-workers [317], which indicates that the original LiCoO2 would not suffer thermal degradation up to 450 °C, but the charged Li x CoO2 (x <1) would have O2 release at 300 °C from the {012} and {104} facets. Based on this understanding, they intentionally coated a layer of reduced graphene oxides on the LCO surface to form an impermeable layer preventing the O2 release [318]. A similar thermal instability and oxygen release behavior was also reported by an in situ heating study of the charged P2-Na x CoO2 cathode for NIBs [320]. Another recent study by Sun et al. [319] further clarified the oxygen vacancy migration-driven mechanism for the release of O2 and the loss of Co cations in LCO cathodes. Ni-rich layered LiNi x Mn y CozO2 (NMC) is another class of widely used commercial cathode material in LIBs [333] and thus has attracted various in situ heating TEM studies to uncover the degradation mechanisms [321–325]. For example, Yan et al. [323] reported the thermally induced mechanical failure of delithiated (charged) LiNi0.6Mn0.2Co0.2O2 (NMC622) cathodes for LIBs. Fig. 11 (A) displays atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM images showing that intragranular cracks can form after the room-temperature delithiation and propagate explosively when the temperature is elevated to 275 °C. The crystal structure was found to transform from the layered spinel to the rock-salt in the crack regions. The heating-induced intergranular cracking would cause surface phase heterogeneity and oxygen release, which further induces thermal stresses to drive continued crack nucleation and propagation. The failure mechanism has revealed the coupled thermal and mechanical degradation of layer cathode materials under complicated electrochemical and thermo-mechanical conditions. Additional in situ heating TEM experiments were also conducted to identify the mechanical and thermal degradations of charged LiNi0.4Mn0.4Co0.2O2 (NMC442) [324], LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) [321,322], and LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 (NMC333) [325], as well as Al-doped Ni-rich Li x Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 (NCA80) [325–327] and Li x Ni0.835Co0.15Al0.015O2 (NCA83) [327] cathodes, which consistently show the spinel-to-rocksalt structural transformation and oxygen release.
