It is generally believed that the layered NMC cathodes with higher Ni content are vulnerable to thermal instabilities at less elevated temperatures, which necessitates a good balance between storage capacity and electrochemical window. Co-free layered LiNiO2 (LNO) and doped LNO cathodes recapture the attention as a promising group of cathode materials for LIBs [334,335]. Most recently, Xin and co-workers [328] performed an in situ heating TEM study to reveal the atomic-scale phase transformation and oxygen loss mechanism in LNO and Ti/Mg-codoped LNO cathodes for LIBs. Fig. 11(B) displays the time-sequential electron diffraction patterns and HRTEM images showing structural transformations of delithiated LNO and doped LNO as a function of temperature. The heating-induced transformation of delithaited LNO includes the rapid transition from O1 to spinel structure at 210 °C and then to disordered spinel at 230 °C and rock-salt structure at 300 °C. A similar phase transformation pathway was also found in delithiated doped LNO but with a substantial delay in the temperature scale. Further 3D electron tomography reconstruction indicated the cracking formation in discrete (003) planes and the preferential propagation along the [001] direction. This work uncovered the concurrent structural and mechanical degradation mechanism in Co-free LNO and confirmed the effectiveness of Ti/Mg dopants to suppress the formation of internal cracks and the propagation of surface-initiated cracks toward the interior region. Overall, the knowledge obtained from in situ heating TEM studies has provided insightful implications and guidelines to design high-capacity and high-stability cathodes for LIBs. In summary, in situ and operando TEM techniques have undoubtedly offered fundamental insights to help new developments of battery science and engineering from new materials discovery to architecture design and property optimization. However, there are also inevitable limitations inherited from the nature of TEM, i.e., the sample thickness has to be sufficiently thin (preferably below 100 nm) to allow good electron transparency and imaging quality, and the active materials are sparsely dispersed under a large reaction environment. These factors may result in the difficulties to develop one-to-one correlation from the localized observation and measurement to the global battery properties and performance, because the current density and mechanical stress through a small cross-sectional area as well as the local electrochemical condition surrounding an individual nano-component may be much different from those in real battery cells. To avoid potential artifacts and the misinterpretation of in situ TEM results, it is suggested to carry out such experiments in correlative multi-modalities and at complementary length scales, such as comparing in situ observations with post-mortem characterizations, combining sub-nanometer imaging with sub-micron electron diffraction, and correlating TEM results with micron-to-millimeter scale X-ray imaging, diffraction, and spectroscopy techniques. In addition, the dimension and geometry dependent electro-chemo-mechanical behaviors may also be clarified with the help of multiscale modeling and calculation. 2.3 In situ TEM for photovoltaics Solar energy harvesting technology has been increasingly utilized as an alternative to generate electricity for industrial sectors and residential customers [6]. Solar cells based on halide perovskites have become the most popular photovoltaic materials in the past decade due to their high-power conversion efficiency [336]. Toward the rapid development of photovoltaic technology, in situ TEM has played an important role in addressing fundamental questions regarding the degradation of perovskites affected by physical and environmental factors. The previous in situ TEM studies of photovoltaic materials are summarized in Table 3 . Here, we will select representative case studies to describe the state-of-the-art progress in this area. 2.3.1 In situ heating for solid-state transformation in halide perovskites The long-term thermal stability is critical for perovskite solar cells (PSCs) since they have to operate in direct sunlight bearing with the temperature cycling and heat dissipation. The heat-induced degradation has been extensively studied by in situ TEM on halide perovskites, and the majority of which was focused on methylammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3), one of the most commonly used PSC devices. Divitini et al. [337] reported the in situ TEM observation of the thermal response of four different MAPbI3 perovskite samples at elevated temperatures. The four samples were prepared through different processing routes, i.e., double-step vacuum conversion (Sample A), glovebox conversion (B), air conversion (C), and single-step approach in the glovebox (D). Fig. 12 (A) shows the HAADF-STEM images of four samples at different stages of heating, which do not show visible changes in the perovskite layer of all samples until 150 °C. At higher temperatures, the degradation of the perovskite layer occurred to form small PbI2 particles and aggregate at the TiO2 interface in Samples A, B and D, which was observed in Sample C. The exposure to air during fabrication causes the inhomogeneous perovskite layer. This work demonstrated the strong impact of fabrication routes on the degradation mechanism of MAPbI3 perovskites. Additional in situ heating experiments on MAPbI3 perovskite confirmed that trigonal PbI2 is precipitated from the amorphized MAPbI3 layer via intermediate states during thermal degradation [338], and also suggested that the attack of CH3NH3 + organic moiety by oxygen may be an alternative degradation mechanism during ambient air exposure at room temperature [339]. As for other halide perovskites, Zhang et al. [341] reported that CsPbBr3 could possess superb stability at temperatures up to 690 K in high vacuum (∼10−5 Pa); Seo et al. [343] found that triple-cation Cs/FA/MA-perovskites (FA denoting formamidinium) have slightly improved thermal stability (failure at 170 °C) comparing to single-cation MAPbI3 perovskites (failure at 150 °C). In general, these studies have provided new insights into the fundamental correlations between morphology, chemical composition, and thermal stability of organolead halide perovskites. Comparing to the above in situ heating experiments in high vacuum, it is more desired to study the thermal degradation under controlled environmental conditions relevant to the solar cell’s working conditions. In situ heating TEM through gas-cell holders or ETEM can uniquely satisfy this purpose. Fan et al. [340] reported the first in situ gas-cell TEM study on the thermal degradation behavior of MAPbI3 perovskites. They carried out in situ heating experiments under vacuum and dry air ambients using a MEMS-based gas cell setup. Fig. 12(B) shows the in situ time-resolved electron diffraction patterns during thermal treatment of MAPbI3 at 85 °C in vacuum, which indicates the phase transformation from tetragonal MAPbI3 to trigonal PbI2 through the proposed layer-by-layer degradation mechanism. Comparing with the in situ heating in 700 Torr dry air, the same evolution pathway was confirmed, meaning that the thermal effect is the sole dominant cause for degradation of the MAPbI3 perovskite. It was also demonstrated that the encapsulation of MAPbI3 with BN flakes could effectively suppress the surface Pb+ and I− dangling bonds to improve thermal stability. Apart from this work, Aguiar et al. [342] performed in situ heating in ETEM to identify the crystallization process of FAPbI3 perovskites in argon, nitrogen, and oxygen gas with and without the presence of water vapor. The results indicated that the porous microstructure is dependent on the amount of water vapor. The results revealed that the exposure to water vapor would lead to a metastable porous film, regardless of the presence of argon, nitrogen, or oxygen, and that the optimal crystallization temperature is 175 °C. These studies have provided guidance for mitigating the thermal degradation and improving the structural stability of halide perovskites for solar cells. 2.3.2 In situ electrical biasing for halide perovskites It is also of great interest to study the impact of electrical bias on the stability and degradation of halide perovskite materials. The in situ TEM holder with a MEMS-based biasing chip is the ideal tool for this purpose. Jeangros et al. [344] reported an in situ TEM study on electrical bias-induced degradation mechanisms of MAPbI3-based PSCs at the nanoscale. The nanosized solar cell was fabricated on a MEMS biasing chip using FIB from a photovoltaic thin film consisting of Au contact, hole transport layer (HTL), MAPbI3 perovskite absorber, electron transport layer (ETL), and indium tin oxide (ITO) front electrode. Fig. 13 (A) shows the HAADF images of the perovskite cell under ± 6 V biasing for 10 min, in which the change in HAADF intensity reveals the ionic migration of heavy elements (Pb+ and I−) at the MAPbI3–HTL interface and the void formation at the MAPbI3–ETL interface (both marked by arrows). The formation of PbI2 nanoparticles and voids was related to the interface energy dissipation process that depends on the polarity of the MAPbI3–hole transport layer, which may contribute to the decrease in cell efficiency during operation. These findings provided valuable implications to improve the stability of photovoltaic devices. Jung et al. [345] performed in situ biasing experiments on MAPbI3 solar cells using the type (iv) setup (Fig. 8A) adapted in a Nanofactory holder. They used an unique n–i–p regular structure consisting of fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO)/compact-TiO2/mesoporous-TiO2/MAPbI3/Spiro-OMeTAD/Au contact, which allows to isolate the effects of an electrical bias from other factors affecting the stability of perovskite device. Fig. 13(B) displays STEM images and diffraction patterns of two samples under in situ biasing, which show no noticeable morphological change immediately after applying +1 V forward bias for 1 h, but significant change to amorphous MAPbI3 with the formation of PbI2 after several days’ storage in Ar-filled glove box. This biasing-induced degradation is in stark contrast to the air exposure-induced degradation (formation of PbI2 without amorphization), which was attributed to oxygen migration to the MAPbI3 from the TiO2 ETL under prolonged modest forward bias. This work provided direct evidence of electrical biasing-induced degradation mechanism close to the actual operating condition of PSC devices and suggested new strategies to mitigate the influence of moisture and oxygen in PSC applications. So far, only these two relevant studies have been reported in the literature. New opportunities are allowed for in situ TEM to study thermal, electrical, and environmental degradations in organic-inorganic hybrid perovskite materials and solar cell devices. The research on this topic is still at the embryonic stage and needs more systemic investigations to advance forward. 2.4 In situ TEM for thermoelectrics Thermoelectric materials offer unique power generation by directly converting thermal energy into electricity and thus enable an environment-friendly energy conversion technology [7]. The major effort has been focused on improving the thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT) defined by ZT = (S 2 σ/κ)T, where S, σ and κ are Seebeck coefficient, electrical conductivity, and the thermal conductivity, respectively. Due to the high operating temperature of thermoelectric devices, in situ heating TEM is necessarily needed to characterize the evolution of structure and composition and their impacts on the optimization of those interdependent factors for an overly high ZT value. The previous in situ TEM studies on thermoelectric materials are summarized in Table 4 . Here, we will use representative case studies to describe the state-of-the-art progress in this area. SnSe is a stable layered compound with intrinsically ultralow thermal conductivity and high electric conductivity, manifesting great potential for a high thermoelectric ZT. However, the temperature-dependent phase transition may nonlinearly vary the ZT value. Zhao et al. [346] synthesized SnSe single crystals that exhibit an unprecedented ZT of 2.6 ± 0.3 at 923 K. They performed in situ heating TEM to identify the structural evolution during the phase transition. Fig. 14 (A) shows a series of electron diffraction patterns taken from room temperature to elevated temperatures, which confirms the reversible phase transition from the Pnma space group at room temperature to the Cmcm space group at 800 K. There was only a subtle angular variation between specific orientations throughout the entire process, which suggests that the transition between Pnma and Cmcm space groups is a displacive second-order phase transition with the very close relationship of the two structures. Recently, Dargusch et al. [347] reported a comprehensive in situ TEM and XRD study on polycrystalline Sn0.98Se, which exhibits a continuous phase transition from Pnma to Cmcm space groups between 573 to 843 K, rather than a sudden transition at 800 K. PbTe is another high-performance thermoelectric material with especially outstanding ZT in the intermediate temperature range. He and co-workers [348] reported the enhanced ZT of 1.8 at 773 K by adding 3% Sb into 0.1% PbI2-doped PbTe. This dramatic increase of ZT was believed due to the dual-site point defects formed after the addition of Sb. In situ heating TEM was used to observe the structural evolution of Sb precipitates at elevated temperatures to interpret the improved thermoelectric properties. Fig. 14(B) shows a series of in situ HAADF-STEM images that capture the evolution of Sb precipitates from 373 to 663 K. It was found that the contrast of Sb precipitates varies with increasing temperature, appearing as the change from dark to bright contrast. It is indicative of the dissolution of Sb precipitates into the PbTe matrix at higher temperatures. The diffusion-controlled Sb dissolution would further exchange positions with the Pb and Te atoms in the crystal lattice to form dual-substitutional defect sites, which was confirmed by DFT calculations and considered responsible for the decrease of thermal conductivity. Cu2Se is a fast-ion conductor and promising thermoelectric material with ultralow lattice thermal conductivity. Bai et al. [349] observed the phase transition from α- to β-Cu2Se induced by the temperature rise through in situ heating TEM operated at room temperature up to 423 K. Using the combined in situ electron diffraction and atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM imaging, it was found that the α to β transition occurs at 393 K, associated with Cu-ions hopping from ordered to disordered sites to produce a large elastic strain, which is related to the reduction of the carrier mobility and the increase of electrical resistance. Furthermore, the authors also investigated the microstructure evolution of Cu2Se under in situ biasing and heating close to the actual working conditions [353]. It was found that a defective interfacial phase can appear along the boundaries of the Cu2Se grains when subject to external current or elevated temperature. Fig. 14(C) shows such a defective interfacial phase as an α-Cu2Se domain formed between two ordered β-Cu2Se domains under a current of 1.3 mA. With further biasing at ∼200 °C to mimic the real thermoelectric working condition, the α-Cu2Se domain remained stable while the interfacial defects disappeared; when the temperature was increased to >400 °C, the Bi-rich phase started to precipitate. The hierarchical microstructure organization consisting of low-ion-conducting α-Cu2Se domains bounded with Bi precipitates would effectively limit the Cu migration and enable high thermoelectric properties. There are also additional in situ TEM studies on other thermoelectric materials, such as the thermally induced solid-phase transformation in pseudo-layered Sb2Te3(GeTe)17 [350], Cu2S [351], and (ZnSb)72.7(SnTe)27.3 [352]. Overall, the previous work on various thermoelectric materials has provided new knowledge and specific insights into novel design strategies to achieve high ZT materials for thermoelectric applications. 2.5 Cryo-TEM for radiation-sensitive energy materials Cryogenic TEM (cryo-TEM) is generally referred to the TEM methodology applied to specimens that are cooled to a low temperature inside the microscope. It is also known as, in particular to the structural biology community, cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM), which is the Method of the Year 2015 [354] and the cornerstone of the 2017 Nobel Prize in Chemistry [355], and has revolutionized the characterization of biological materials with near-atomic resolution [356]. Similar to biomolecular materials in life sciences, certain materials of interest in physical sciences are also vulnerable to high-energy electron beam radiation damage in TEM, including polymers, MOFs, ultrathin nanomaterials, lithium and its derivatives, and halides, which are extensively used in energy-related technologies. Cryo-TEM presents an effective approach to characterize these radiation-sensitive energy materials in their native states and free of electron-beam damage [357]. Although largely under-utilized, cryo-TEM has shown its profound impact on energy materials research [358–360], as summarized in Table 5 and highlighted in Fig. 15 . Here, we will use several representative studies in the research of LIBs, PSCs, and MOF catalysts to describe the recent progress in this field. 2.5.1 Cryo-TEM for rechargeable batteries In the battery research, early contributions have been made by Cui et al. [361], Meng et al. [367], and Kourkoutis et al. [371] groups to unveil the hidden puzzles buried in the lithium/electrolyte interface. The Cui group [361] reported the first atomic-resolution TEM imaging of Li metal and its interface with the SEI at cryogenic conditions. It was demonstrated that rapid freezing in liquid nitrogen could effectively preserve and stabilize Li metal dendrites, which tend to form faceted single-crystalline nanowires along <111>, <110>, or <211> directions. Fig. 15(A) shows two distinct types of interfacial SEI nanostructures on the surface of Li metal, i.e., mosaic-type model and multilayer model, formed in commercial EC/DEC and fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) electrolytes, respectively. This work implies that the ordered multilayer structure has better mechanical durability than the random mosaic structure, leading to improved robustness during battery cycling. Further cryo-TEM experiments done by Meng and co-workers identified the structures of electrochemically deposited Li [367] and unreacted Li [366] within the SEI, which together contributes to the total inactive (“dead”) Li causing the capacity loss in batteries. The former study has identified the amorphous nature of the electrochemically deposited Li. Fig. 15(C) shows TEM images of two distinct morphologies of the inactive Li generated in high-concentration LiFSI/LiTFSI/DME electrolyte and commercial EC/EMC electrolyte, which are found embedded in a sheet-like SEI layer or isolated in a whisker-like SEI layer, respectively. These findings provide insights into mechanisms for the formation of inactive Li and strategies for improving the efficiency of Li plating and stripping. Besides the cryo-TEM imaging, additional analytical work was performed by Kourkoutis and co-workers [371] to determine the elemental distribution of SEI using the cryo-STEM-EELS method. The samples were made by cryo-FIB from the SEI regions of cycled coin cells, which contain Li dendrites in two types: (I) less curved shape with larger (few μm) contact area, and (II) tortuous shape with smaller (sub-μm) contact area, suggesting that type II dendrites are more prone to disconnect from the electrode to become dead Li. Fig. 15(B) shows STEM-EELS elemental mapping of the interfacial regions surrounding two types of dendrites. The type I dendrite has an extended (300–500 nm) SEI layer with high carbon and oxygen concentrations, whereas the type II dendrite is covered by a thin (∼20 nm) carbon-free oxygen-rich layer. The detailed compositions of dendrites were analyzed by EELS fine structures of C-K edge, revealing the existence of a considerable amount of LiH in type II dendrites. This work demonstrates the feasibility of cryo-STEM-EELS for probing the nanoscale structure and composition of Li dendrites and SEI layers, offering practical implications for mitigating the detrimental interfacial reactions in LIBs. The success in these early studies has stimulated continuously increasing efforts in the battery community and led to considerable progress in the past few years. It is worth noting that cryo-TEM has been applied to study Li metal and SEI in LIBs [362–365,368–373,375–378,404–408], cathode-electrolyte interphase (CEI) in LIBs [387,388], Li-S batteries [389–391], NIBs [392–394], and and KIB [396], in addition to the relevant studies done by cryo-FIB-SEM technique [380–386,395]. We expect cryo-TEM to open more opportunities for battery research that lead to new discoveries and breakthroughs in the future. 2.5.2 Cryo-TEM for perovskite solar cells In the photovoltaic research, the prevailing halide perovskite materials are notorious for their extreme sensitivity to electron-beam damage, which may cause artifacts and misinterpretation of experiments; therefore, low-dose and cryogenic techniques are typically required for meaningful characterization at the nanoscale [409]. Only a few cryo-TEM studies have been reported for halide perovskite materials at this early stage, with details described in the following. Cui and co-workers [397] developed a successful experimental protocol for atomic-resolution cryo-TEM imaging of MAPbI3 under various operation conditions. Fig. 15(D) shows the HRTEM images taken from both conventional and cryo-TEM. The conventional TEM images indicate the fast decomposition of MAPbI3 into PbI2 at a high electron dose (500 e− Å−2 at room temperature). In contrast, cryo-TEM can preserve the sample’s intrinsic structure at a lower electron dose (12 e− Å−2 at −175 °C) and resolve individual [PbI6]4− octahedral and MA+ molecule column with the 1.49 Å spatial resolution limit. Given that the electron-beam damage generates the same decomposition products as the degradation caused by other environmental factors, it is vital to define a valid imaging criterion to truly distinguish the structure change arising from the targeting factors instead of the electron beam itself. Using this cryo-TEM method, they further studied the structural evolutions upon exposure to UV light and ambient moisture. The results suggest that MAPbI3 does not decompose under UV illumination for 1 h and that surface roughening occurs even with only 10 s exposure to moisture; both contradict previous findings obtained by conventional TEM characterization. This work sets an important benchmark for the application of cryo-TEM in PSC research. Most recently, Gu and co-workers [398] reported a cryo-TEM study on atomic surface structures and planar defects of MAPbI3 single crystals. The electron dose rate for cryo-TEM was controlled <50 e− Å−2 s−1 to keep the MAPbI3 structure intact, which exhibits atomic steps and stacking faults on {200}T surfaces. Fig. 15(E) shows cryo-HRTEM images of the MAI–MAI type stacking faults of the (002)T surface, which was confirmed by image simulations and found to be stable after electron exposure of 32 s (total dose ∼1504 e− Å−2 at –190 °C). The results suggest that the high-density MAI-type stacking faults play a crucial role as the micro-interface to facilitate the charge separation and prevent the electron-hole recombination within the MAPbI3 crystal. Nevertheless, there are also debating questions regarding the effect of cryogenic cooling on susceptibility to electron radiation at this early stage [409]. A few recent studies have utilized electron diffraction to monitor the structural degradation at different cryogenic conditions, which show that rapid crystal-to-amorphous transition occurs in MAPbI3 at –180 °C with the dose rate of ∼2 e− Å−2 s−1 for 720 s [400], at –180 °C with the dose rate of ∼1 e− Å−2 s−1 for 150 s [399], and in CsPbBr3 at –120 °C with the total dose of ∼2 × 104 e− Å−2 [401]. This may imply two types of electron-beam-induced degradation mechanisms: decomposition at room temperature and amorphization at cryo temperatures. It is also interesting to note that the low-temperature amorphization took less time (with the same dose rate) than the room temperature degradation [399,400], putting one in a dilemma to evaluate the benefit of cryocooling. Such inconsistencies may be attributed to the discrepancy in cryo-instrumentation, cryo-transfer method, sample conditions, and experimental parameters, which needs additional careful control experiments to clarify. For cryo-TEM of halide perovskites, special caution should be paid to ensure reliable data and trustful interpretation. 2.5.3 Cryo-TEM for metal-organic framework catalysts In the catalysis research, MOFs have become one of the most attractive porous solid supports for heterogeneous catalysts and single-atom catalysts [410]. However, MOFs are another group of materials highly susceptible to electron beam; therefore, low-dose and cryo-TEM methods are critically needed to determine the atomic structures of MOFs. Despite the majority of work being done with low-dose TEM techniques [411,412], the use of cryo-TEM in MOF research has emerged recently, with exemplary results highlighted below. After the prior success in battery studies, Cui and co-workers further extended the cryo-TEM methodology to investigate the crystalline structures and host1guest interactions of MOFs [402]. Zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) holds great promise in many applications, including catalysis, gas separation, and sensing, due to its unique crystallographic structures and nonperiodic local features. Using a modified flash-freezing protocol, the crystal structure of ZIF-8 was captured along the [111] zone axis with near-atomic resolution (1.86 Å), as shown in Fig. 15(G). The cryo-HRTEM images show Zn clusters in the hexagonal lattice with and without CO2 occupancy in the open channels along the [111] projection. It was found that the ZIF-8 crystal lattice would expand ∼3% along <011> and <002> directions upon adsorption of CO2 molecules, which provides insights into the host-guest interactions of gas molecules or catalytic groups for diverse applications. For imaging the same ZIF-8 MOF, the resolution of 1.86 Å (total dose of 25 e− Å−2) obtained by cryo-TEM in this work outperforms the resolution of 2.1 Å (total dose of 4.1 e− Å−2) previously achieved by low-dose HRTEM [413], demonstrating that cryo-TEM can better stabilize MOFs with higher dose tolerance at low temperatures and improve the spatial resolution as compared to the room temperature low-dose HRTEM. Recently, Patterson and co-workers [403] employed time-resolved cryo-TEM [414] to track the structural evolution of protein-MOF (p-MOF) hybrid systems in order to develop the controlled synthesis of MOF materials. Specifically, the presented model p-MOF system contains bovine serum albumin (BSA) and ZIF-8 in 2-methylimidazole (HmIm) aqueous solution. In this scenario, cryo-TEM plays dual roles: (1) as low-temperature protection to prevent ZIF-8 from electron beam damage, and (2) as a thermal fixation to freeze a dynamic process and allow observations of transient structural changes. By repeating the induction-fixation procedures at a series of time delays, a whole picture of the nucleation and growth of BSA-ZIF-8 was captured, as shown in Fig. 15(F). The results revealed that the formation of the transient amorphous phase determines two distinct pathways for the following crystallization of ZIF-8: (1) the dissolution-recrystallization of highly hydrated amorphous particles, or (2) the direct solid-state transformation of a protein-rich amorphous phase. This work provided practical implications for the general understanding of crystallization mechanisms and the future synthetic strategies for MOFs. It is also demonstrated that time-resolved cryo-TEM is a valid alternative to in situ LCTEM for studying dynamic phenomena of electron-beam-sensitive materials. Overall, cryo-TEM offers unique capabilities complementary to other in situ TEM techniques, which opens new opportunities for studying sensitive materials used for diverse energy-related applications. Nevertheless, there are limitations to be carefully taken into account in practice, especially to determine (1) whether the target material would exhibit the same microscopic behaviors or undergo a phase transition to change the crystal structure under low temperatures, (2) to what extent the kinetics of the target dynamic process is reduced at low temperatures and whether it allows feasible real-time observations as compared to regular conditions. Therefore, the prior knowledge or experimental validation is required to justify the suitable application of cryo-TEM for the materials with low-temperature transformations. It is also worth noting that the in situ cryogenic input can be used in different ways and may not necessarily warrant the real-time observation. For reliable cryo-TEM experiments, feasible standard operating protocols are urgently needed to allow valid selections of cryogenic temperature, electron dose (or dose rate), and other instrumental parameters. We expect a drastic increase in cryo-TEM utilization in the research of energy materials in the foreseeable future. 3 AI-enabled microscopy data analytics and applications for in situ TEM As a subset of AI methods, ML has been increasingly applied to the analysis of microscopy data in physical sciences and biomedical imaging. ML aims to enable computers to automatically perform designated tasks without the need for explicit programming, which includes two basic approaches, i.e., supervised ML and unsupervised ML, depending on whether human intervention is needed or not. Specifically, supervised ML uses labeled data to train models for accurate outcome prediction, while unsupervised ML uses algorithms to analyze unlabeled data and discover the hidden patterns underlying the datasets. DL is a subfield of ML that uses artificial neural networks to mimic the way how the human brain processes data. DL leverages the large depth of the comprised layers in neural networks to offer more effective learning models with less dependence on human intervention. As a consequence, DL algorithms are more complex to tackle larger data volume and thus require more powerful hardware and computing resources. The rapid development of ML and DL algorithms has also brought benefits to advance the AI-enabled data analytics in electron microscopy. TEM-based methodologies can generate data in different types, such as images (2D TEM/STEM images and 3D electron tomography), diffraction patterns (convergent beam, select area, and scanning precession electron diffraction, i.e., CBED, SAED, and SPED, respectively), and EELS spectra. These TEM-generated graphic or spectral types of data can be combined into high-dimensional datasets in energy-filtered TEM, STEM-EELS spectrum-imaging, 4D-STEM diffractive imaging, and time-sequenced in situ TEM, which are the anticipated scenarios for implementation of ML/DL methods. ML-based approaches have been applied to TEM data analysis and evolved rapidly in the past few years. We have conducted a thorough search in the literature and extensively summarized the relevant studies to our best knowledge, as shown in Table 6 . The latest progress and the state-of-the-art in this field are described below. 3.1. Machine learning for TEM image processing In general, in situ TEM imaging generates datasets containing images as a function of time that are relevant to a specific sample in a dynamic process. There is an urgent need to process and analyze the acquired image data effectively and efficiently. Thanks to AI, imaging processing has been significantly improved and automated by ML to solve routine tasks in image recognition, segmentation, localization, classification, restoration, representation, interpretation, and so on. Leveraging the available algorithms and tools, AI-enabled image processing has been applied to help TEM analysis in many aspects [20–23]. 3.1.1. Machine learning for analyzing atomic structures Detecting atomic positions, recognizing atom species, and identifying atomic defects are of fundamental importance for the analysis of atomic-resolution TEM/STEM images. STEM imaging is more advantageous for this purpose because of its straightforward Z-contrast for easy interpretation. Kalinin and co-works [415–422] have made the leading contribution in this area to develop ML approaches for extracting latent information from atomic STEM images. For example, Ziatdinov et al. [415] utilized the FCN DL approach combined with the Laplacian of Gaussian (LoG) blob detection to identify the positions of atoms and defects (i.e., Si in graphene) from atomically resolved STEM images, as shown in Fig. 16 (A). The following DL-based analysis can further localize and classify the defect type (foreign dopants or vacancies) and coordination (threefold or fourfold), which was demonstrated in graphene and Mo1− x W x Se2. Later, using the similar encoder-decoder type DCCNs along with the Gaussian mixture model (GMM), the team conducted the unsupervised classification of five distinct atomic defect structures and identified the spatiotemporal trajectories of the detected defects in a model 2D transition metal chalcogenide (TMC) WS2 [417], as shown in Fig. 16(B). With these powerful ML tools, more studies have been performed on the electron-beam-induced transformations in Mo-doped WS2 [415,416] and Si-doped graphene [418–420], as well as extended to ferroelectric complex oxides [421,422]. Recently, Huang and co-workers [423] applied DL using FCNs with the ResUNet architecture to locate and classify the four distinct types of point defects in WSe2–2 x Te2 x . By comparing the positions of each atomic column on class-averaged defect images to the positions measured in a defect-free, class-averaged reference image, the 2D displacement vectors were obtained, which were then used to map out the 2D strain fields of the single-atom defects sub-pm precision, as shown in Fig. 16(C). So far, these well-established DL models have manifested their feasibility and effectiveness in many 2D materials; meanwhile, the open-source TEMImageNet training library recently deployed by Xin et al. [424] will provide more training data to help the community validate a broader range of materials. Retrieving the height information from projected 2D images is vital to resolving the 3D atomic structure of the specimen. However, unlike the ultrathin 2D materials whose thicknesses are uniform and have nearly no influence on the contrast of atomic columns, the analysis for the samples with thickness variation all over the atom columns becomes a challenging and non-trivial task. Schiøtz and co-workers [425] applied the FCN-based DL model to a single Au nanoparticle model system to identify the pixel-wise position of atomic columns and count the number of atoms of each atom column, which was entirely based on the training of synthetic data obtained from HRTEM image simulations, as shown in Fig. 17 (A). It was found that the detecting and tracking of atom column are stable to microscope parameters and noise, as validated by in situ ETEM of Au/CeO2. In contrast, the counting accuracy is directly related to the HRTEM imaging conditions such as electron dose and tilt angles off the zone axis, which are potential hurdles for the validation in actual experimental TEM images. Later, Mashayek et al. [426] extended this DL classification model and further implemented the regression algorithm for the determination of the atomic column heights in the experimental HRTEM images of a single Au nanoparticle, as shown in Fig. 17(B). Further, the prediction of atomic column height can be used for the Wulff construction of nanoparticles to generate a dataset of physically realistic structures. Nevertheless, the evaluation of the predictions on a particular structure requires the ground truth experimentally determined by atomic electron tomography, which was lacking in this study. The improvement of predictive capabilities will significantly facilitate its application for future in situ TEM studies. 3.1.2. Machine learning for detecting nanoscale morphologies and microstructures Image segmentation is one of the most common tasks in TEM data analysis routines, which necessitates accuracy and high speed to process large volume images generated by in situ TEM experiments. Besides the pixel-wise segmentation of individual atom columns, DL can also offer effective solutions for the semantic segmentation of TEM and STEM images on the levels of single particles and microstructures [427,431,447]. Recently, Stach and co-workers [427] reported a case study on the semantic segmentation of nanoparticles using CNN-based DL models. They focused on a model system of Au nanoparticle catalysts that would change their sizes and morphologies during the Ostwald ripening process observed by in situ ETEM. The U-Net CNN architecture was implemented to segment nanoparticles in HRTEM images and demonstrated its robustness in consistent identification of all nanoparticles with varying sizes, though slight variations in the edge detection still present, as shown in Fig. 18 (A). By systematic comparison of CNN learning parameters, the results suggest that the regularization by batch normalization is more effective than the increase in depth or complexity of a CNN, which provides useful guidelines for more generalizable segmentation tasks. Chen and co-workers [428] implemented the same U-Net DL model to the in situ LCTEM study on the motion, chemical reaction, and self-assembly of Au nanoparticles in solution environments. Based on the accurate segmentation of particle boundaries by the U-Net model, the shape evolution trajectory of Au nanoparticles during an etch process was detected as a function of time, as shown in Fig. 18(C). This etching behavior was found to be highly curvature-dependent. It is also reported that other ML methods [429,430] have also been applied to study dynamic processes during in situ TEM/STEM experiments. These studies have proven the feasibility and readiness for general in situ TEM experiments in liquid and gas environments. Meanwhile, Zhu and co-workers [431] presented another case study on semantic segmentation of microstructures in diffraction contrast imaging (DCI) STEM images of steels using the DefectSegNet CNN architecture. The shape irregularity and distribution inhomogeneity of nonperiodic crystallographic defects make the semantic segmentation of microstructures very challenging in practical TEM and STEM images. Using supervised DL via the DefectSegNet framework, three prototypic defect microstructures, including dislocations, precipitates, and voids, were identified and segmented with high pixel-wise accuracy. Fig. 18(B) shows an example of the dislocation detection in the steel matrix with complicated background contrast. This work has underscored the effectiveness of DL-enhanced image segmentation for complex TEM and STEM images with large contrast variations. Morgan et al. [432] have also done similar work to detect dislocation loops in FeCrAl alloys using the CNN-based DL approach. Most recently, they utilized the YOLO model-based DL to detect and track the dynamic motion of a single defect in the FeCrAl alloy during in situ ion-irradiation experiments [433]. Fig. 18(D) shows the motion trajectory of the defect throughout its lifespan. Such analysis was applied to in situ TEM videos to detect the trajectories of all interested defects automatically, and the statistical analysis of the trajectory data further revealed the relationship between the effective diffusion coefficient and the median defect size. These early demonstrations provide important benchmarks for improving the fidelity in detecting and tracking complex features from in situ TEM/STEM experiments. 3.1.3. Machine learning for improving 3D electron tomography Electron tomography is a TEM-based technique that can reconstruct 3D models of the object by back-projection of the tilt-series images taken at different angles. The “missing wedge” problem is a common artifact for electron tomography due to the limitation of tilting angles blocked by the sample holder. ML-based image restoration approach can offer an effective way to recover the missing information by inpainting the defective region using the trained CNN framework [434]. The same concept has also been applied to solve the missing-wedge issue of electron tomography. Xin and co-workers [435] developed a joint DL model combining the U-Net structure with the GAN to inpaint the sinogram and retrieve the unacquired projection information. The joint model includes two GAN networks to separately solve sinogram inpainting and tomogram de-artifact problems, which were validated by various synthetic data and proven for generalizable use in tomography reconstruction. Later, this group employed the combination of GAN and U-Net++ to build the information recovery and de-artifact model (IRDM) for improving the reconstruction resolution of atomic electron tomography (AET) [436]. Fig. 19 (A) shows 3D AET reconstructions of an Au crystal with and without the IRDM, which demonstrates a significant improvement of resolution from 1.42 to 0.71 Å, as confirmed by the recovered diffraction spots of {440} planes and the enhanced signal to noise ratio (SNR). This work opens the possibility of 3D visualization and quantification of a variety of materials atom by atom. 4D chemical tomography enabled by STEM-EDS or STEM-EELS tilting series requires a larger amount of time and electron dosage for data acquisition, which inevitably leads to the tradeoff between the total acquirable information and the total bearable dose, causing more difficulties in high-quality reconstruction. Most recently, Ye, Lee, and co-workers [437] developed an unsupervised DL method for high-quality 3D STEM-EDS tomography of core-shell InP/ZnSe/ZnS quantum dots, which are susceptible to damage by prolonged electron beam exposure. The key feature of this unsupervised DL model is its self-utilization to generate more high-quality synthetic data for supervised training; the two-step iterative learning assures high-fidelity 4D chemical reconstruction of the core–shell quantum dot, as shown in Fig. 19(B). The successful implementation of DL in data-intense high-dimensional image processing will stimulate more efforts to push it for comprehensive physicochemical analysis of nanoparticles. 3.2. Machine learning for electron diffraction analysis Electron diffraction can be taken with different microscope settings, including the parallel beam SAED and SPED as well as the convergent beam CBED, which carries plentiful crystallographic information and physical properties from the sample. The indexing of diffraction patterns is intricate and time-consuming for human conception and thus needs computer simulation to fit the experimental data, especially for CBED patterns that contain complicated contrast and features. LeBeau and co-workers [438] developed a CNN-based DL approach to automatically analyze position averaged CBED (PACBED) patterns and extract the information of zero-order disk size, center, rotation, specimen thickness, and specimen tilt without human supervision, as shown in Fig. 20 (A). The CNNs are based on the AlexNet architecture, which was trained on simulated CBED libraries of SrTiO3 [100] single crystal to determine the five parameters in two steps—firstly, size, center, and rotation, then sample thickness and tilt angle. The results show that the CNN achieves overall >95% accuracy and significantly outperforms the efficiency of the conventional least square fitting (LSF) method. Later, Voyles and co-workers [439] developed a DL method using two types of CNN models, i.e., the classification CNN (c-CNN) and the regression CNN (r-CNN), based on the VGG16 architecture to predict the sample thickness from CBED patterns. With the CNNs trained on simulated libraries of SrTiO3 [100] single crystal, they showed that the c-CNN is good at fine estimations with high accuracy, whereas the r-CNN is more useful for the classification of defects and lattice structures. These studies have demonstrated feasible ways for automated analysis of CBED, which further enables the fast analysis of massive 4D STEM datasets using DL approaches [440–442]. SAED is a common method to determine the crystallographic orientation and symmetry of crystalline materials. It is mandatory to index the on-axis SAED patterns taken from multiple orientations for the rigid determination of a crystal structure, which may often be obstructed by experimental limitations. Reliable identification of crystal structures using a limited number of SAED patterns or those on obscure high-index orientations is highly desired. Aguiar et al. [443] developed a CNN-based DL model to determine crystal structures from SAED patterns without priori knowledge. The CNN model was heavily trained on simulated diffraction peak positions of 538000 materials in all representative space groups that are automatically mined from public materials databases such as Open Crystallography Database, Materials Project Database, American Mineralogist Crystallographic Databases, and Inorganic Crystal Structure Database. Fig. 20(B) shows the validation of the structure prediction over multiple crystal families from low- to high-symmetry, which can be specifically classified into the corresponding lattice systems. It was demonstrated that the model is robust and efficient to perform generalized crystallographic classification. It is also noted that Martineau et al. [444] reported the application of unsupervised ML methods to achieve automated dimensionality reduction and signal unmixing and extract the salient microstructure features from experimental SPED patterns. 3.3. Machine learning for spectroscopy analysis EELS is a sophisticated analytical characterization technique that can not only detect the elemental identity but also identify the chemical valence states and electronic structures through the energy-loss near-edge structure (ELNES). However, for multi-component systems, such as oxide-supported metallic nanoparticle heterogeneous catalysts, different energy-loss edges may be overlapped with other characteristic features and affected by the noise caused by background subtraction and zero-loss peak deconvolution, giving rise to difficulties in spatially resolving each constituent component. Most recently, Chi and co-workers [445] developed an unsupervised ML data analysis method to retrieve the spatially resolved trace encapsulation layers that are inaccessible by other means from STEM-EELS spectrum-imaging datasets. The unsupervised learning implemented the automatic target generation process (ATGP) Pre-conditioned Joint-NMF algorithm, which outperforms the commonly used principal component analysis (PCA) and NMF algorithms, to distinguish each component spectra from the STEM-EELS of TiO2 supported Pd nanoparticle (Pd/TiO2), as shown in Fig. 21 (A). The results revealed six distinct components, including the expected Pd nanoparticle and TiO2 support as well as the strong metal-support interaction encapsulation layer that is otherwise invisible by the conventional human-centric processing. Meanwhile, Kalinin et al. [446] also reported another ML-based analysis of STEM-EELS on heterogeneous self-assembled monolayer F/Sn-doped In2O3 nanoparticles in both supervised and unsupervised manners. They built the supervised deep neural network based on the MLP architecture and unsupervised neural network based on the autoencoders (AE) architecture, which were used to separate and classify regions of the sample with physically distinct spectral responses. Fig. 21(B) shows the ML analysis of STEM-EELS mapping labeled by MLP and AE models, in which the supervised MLP method shows the particle isolation closely matched with the human-labeled physically meaningful representations. In contrast, the unsupervised AE method tends to capture the mathematical relevance without human bias. These methods have been validated to be universally applicable for hyperspectral imaging techniques and hold promise for automated analysis of information-intensive STEM-EELS datasets. Recently, Taheri and co-workers [448] reported a ML-enabled denosing and classification for EELS data obtained through rapid acquisition. This team utilized a unsupervised neural network based on the dual Autoencoder-Classifier algorithm to denoise low SNR EELS spectra acquired from a model material SrFeO3-δ (δ denoting the oxygen deficiency) at a high speed of 400 frames per second (fps). The sample underwent an reduction process from nomical SrFeO3 (Fe4+) to SrFeO2.5 (Fe3+), leading to ∼1.6 eV energy shift of the O K-edge onset and the increase of Fe L 3/L 2 white line ratio from 3.8 to 4.6. Although from the experimental perspective, low SNR and the effects of sample thickness variation (plural scattering) and artificial energy shifts jointly impose difficuilties in detection of the oxidation state change, the developed ML approach can successfully denoise the high frame rate spectra and identify the subtle energy shift with accuracy nearly 90%, benchmarking with slowly acquired “ground truths”. This work provides a foundation for rapid data acquisition and reliable analysis of in situ spectroscopy experiments. This project called “RapidEELS” is openly available on GitHub (https://github.com/patecm/rapidEELS). Overall, the AI-enabled microscopy data analytics has leveraged the state-of-the-art ML approaches to enable new capabilities for retrieving information from TEM images, diffraction patterns, and analytical spectra with high accuracy and efficiency. The early development of ML in TEM analytics has been demonstrated in materials that are highly relevant to energy-related applications. However, the current limitations cannot be ignored, specifically the high error-susceptibility and poor interpretability. The accurate ML/DL models require massive unbiased datasets for training, especially for those with more complex architectures. Although data augmentation may be helpful in some extent, it is essential to acquire high-quality raw data in the relevant application domain. However, due to unavoidable instrumental deviations and heterogeneity of material structures, even small local perturbations may cause significant errors in the predicted outcomes. It is known that ML analyzes data in a stochastic process, which does not contain any physical constraints. Therefore, the correct interpretation of results generated by various ML/DL algorithms is critical and remains as a major challenge. A promising solution is to embed the domain knowledge into the ML model to develop physics-informed ML approaches [449]. Considering the model-specific errors, it is also crucial to choose a most appropriate algorithm for a desired electron microscopy task. Despite these disvantages, we expecte that the ML-enhanced methodologies will be generalized for feasible use in automated TEM analytics and in situ TEM experimentation. 4. Concluding remarks 4.1. Summary In this review, we have systematically summarized the recent development of in situ TEM methodologies and AI-enabled data analytics, as well as their applications in energy conversion and storage materials. After the rapid advancement in the past two decades, in situ TEM becomes sophisticated regarding both methodology and instrumentation. We classify the in situ TEM experimentation by the types of specimen setup (open cell, closed cell), in situ stimuli (heating, biasing, lighting, e-beam illuminating, and cryocooling), and reaction environments (vacuum, gas, and liquid), and then use this classification to layout the in situ TEM studies on solid-, liquid-, and gas-phase reactions in energy materials used for catalysts, batteries, photovoltaics, and thermoelectrics, extensively from the literature. It has been doubtlessly demonstrated that in situ TEM offers unprecedented capabilities of real-time imaging and spectroscopy to open new opportunities for the fundamental investigation of diverse topics related to energy materials and devices. Among those studies, in situ heating and biasing have made significant contributions in the fundamental understanding of solid-state reactions and phase transformations in all relevant energy materials, while in situ liquid-cell and gas-cell TEM provides unique platforms to study solid-liquid and solid-gas reactions under reality-relevant environments that is especially essential for catalysts and batteries. It is also noteworthy that cryo-TEM has been increasingly employed to study radiation-sensitive materials, such as polymers, MOFs, alkali metals, and halide perovskites, which has made profound impacts on damage-free characterization and stimulated continuous efforts in the relevant fields. Overall, the knowledge obtained from in situ TEM studies has been leveraged as design principles and practical implications to accelerate the innovation in energy-related technologies. In situ TEM is also a data-intensive technique that requires effective tools to analyze massive datasets. The rapid progress of AI technology has enabled a large variety of ML approaches that have been implemented to solve the pressing data analysis problem for in situ TEM. We have extensively reviewed the recent progress of ML/DL approaches and their applications for TEM data analysis. At this early stage, ML-enhanced data analytics focuses mainly on imaging processing to extract atomistic, morphological, and microstructural features, while some appealing progress has also emerged to achieve automated electron diffraction and spectroscopy analyses. We are enthusiastic that the deep synergy between in situ TEM and ML-enhanced analytics will continue pushing the energy materials research to a new level. 4.2. Challenges and perspectives Despite the remarkable advancements made by in situ TEM, there are still presenting issues to be addressed. Our view on the pressing challenges and future perspectives is given below. First, the impact of electron beam induced material damages and artifacts has to be systematically considered and controlled. As discussed earlier, many in situ setups involving gas, liquid, and sensitive solid species are susceptible to electron beam, which may make the in situ experiments impossible to be observed or generate side effects or misleading information that is irrelevant to the intrinsic properties of the target material or the grand truth of the dynamic process. It is of paramount importance to evaluate the electron-beam influence and figure out a reasonable imaging condition before conducting specific in situ observations. We recommend the following control experiments to be performed as an essential part of design of experiments. (1) For susceptible materials, control experiments with various electron dosage or dose rates are needed to determine whether the target material degradation is limited by the accumulated total dose or the instantaneous dose rate, and the corresponding critical threshold to cause such damages. (2) For the gas and liquid media used in the in situ TEM cells, control experiments are needed to identify the electron-media interactions that occur with the simultaneous target material reaction in the media, and preferably find a controllable way to minimize or separate such effects. (3) For reproducible in situ experiments and reliable interpretation of results, regardless of the types of environmental conditions (e.g., vacuum, gas, liquid), control experiments with beam on and off are necessary to elucidate the effect of electron beam on the target reaction or process. These control experiments should be considered as basis prerequisites and standard operating procedures for in situ TEM investigations, which are expected to be reported in publications to allow the meaningful comparison amongst a large variety of case studies. From the aspect of instrumentation development, new designs of in situ TEM holders are needed to mitigate the degradation of resolution and enable new functionalities. The current closed liquid cells cannot reach a spatial resolution on the atomic level, hindering the tracking of atomistic transformation of materials in solution. A cell with reduced window and liquid layer thickness can improve the resolution and detectability of EELS/EDS signals. The recently demonstrated graphene-sealed SiN x windowed liquid cell may offer a viable solution [450]. It is also desired to incorporate multiple independently tunable stimuli into the MEMS-based TEM cells to allow more complicated in situ experiments solely through the TEM holder without special modification of the TEM column or other ancillaries. Moreover, in situ TEM cells suitable for correlative microscopy techniques are also highly anticipated. For example, MEMS-based gas/liquid cells compatible to both TEM and X-ray setups can enable seamless interchange between different in situ measurements and thus build direct correlation across all relevant length scales. From the aspect of methodology advancement, new in situ TEM approaches with multimodal and multidimensional data acquisition through standard protocols are highly encouraged. Direct correlation between imaging, diffraction, and spectroscopy from a single acquisition can restore a panoramic scenario of the sample, but it is infeasible in TEM mode. However, 4D STEM can simultaneously combine image and diffraction data to link imaging with crystallography of the sample. Further, the conceptual design of “hollow” 4D STEM [451] may directly integrate STEM images with both CBED and EELS all together to enable spatially and crystallographically resolved chemical imaging. It is also critical to standardize the experimental protocols to ensure reliably calibrated sample boundary conditions at all times for meaningful comparison between different trials and various systems. From the aspect of AI-enabled data analysis, deeper engagement of ML with in situ TEM is essentially necessary for autonomous and adaptive microscopy. A major challenge is to enhance the universality of ML in analyzing microscopy data obtained from different materials, in different dimensions, and by different TEM techniques. It is critical that the current demonstration of ML-enhanced data analytics can be expanded to more generalizable domains and to fit more relevant microscopy characterizations. It is expected that the pre-trained ML/DL models will not only accurately process the results from the same type of in situ TEM experiments but also broadly translate to perform new tasks in different material systems for reliable data analysis and prediction. Despite the important benchmarks achieved at this early stage, the lack of robustness and interpretability in current task-specific ML algorithms and models is another big issue. Continued efforts toward the domain-specific training data augmentation and the physics-informed ML approach provide promsing solutions to overcome the limiting barriers. The ultimate goal for AI-enalbed in situ TEM is to allow on-the-fly microscopy data processing and instantaneous interpretation of the ongoing in situ TEM experiment, which, in turn, will predict optimal operating parameters to guide the microscope for the subsequent data acquisitions. This is a challenging task that requires joint efforts from both electron microscopy and data science communities. Overall, from the perspective of energy materials, in situ TEM has already demonstrated its feasibility and powerfulness in tracking dynamic structural and chemical evolutions in previous research. The synergetic development of in situ TEM instrumentation, methodology, and ML-enhanced data analytics will bring new opportunities for making ground-breaking discoveries to solve the pressing challenges in energy and environmental technologies. Lett. 121 (2018) 146101. Hongkui Zheng received his B.S. degree from Hohai University in 2017 and M.S. degree from University of California, Irvine in 2019. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Clemson University. His research work focuses on in situ TEM study of solid-state battery materials. Xiner Lu received her B.S. degree from Southern University of Science and Technology in 2019. She is currently a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Clemson University. Her research work focuses on in situ TEM study of heterogeneous catalysts. Kai He received his Ph.D. from Arizona State University in 2010. After postdoctoral training at University of Maryland and Brookhaven National Laboratory, he joined Northwestern University as a research assistant professor in 2015. Dr. He is currently an assistant professor of the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Clemson University since 2018. His research interests include the development of electron microscopy methodologies and their applications in quantum information sciences and energy-related technologies.

coredata.dc:description: Energy materials are vital to energy conversion and storage devices that make renewable resources viable for electrification technologies. In situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is a powerful approach to characterize the dynamic evolution of material structure, morphology, and chemistry at the atomic scale in real time and in operando. In this review, recent advancements of in situ TEM techniques for studying energy materials, including catalysts, batteries, photovoltaics, and thermoelectrics, are systematically discussed and summarized. The topics include a broad range of material transformations that are in situ stimulated by heating, biasing, lighting, electron-beam illuminating, and cryocooling under vacuum, liquid, or gas environments within TEM, as well as the mechanistic understanding of the associated solid-solid, solid-liquid, and solid-gas reactions elucidated by in situ TEM examination and operando measurements. Special focus is also put on the emerging progress of artificial intelligence enabled microscopy data analytics, including machine learning enhanced tools for retrieving useful information from massive TEM imaging, diffraction, and spectroscopy datasets, highlighting its merits and potential for automated in situ TEM experimentation and analysis. Finally, the pressing challenges and future perspectives on in situ TEM study for energy-related materials are discussed.
